Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: Today, we're doing something different.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: Our friend John Green will read a story from his podcast, The Anthropocene Review.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: We hope you enjoy it, and we'll be back with a regular video soon.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: So, if you've ever been or had a child, you will likely already be familiar with hand stencils.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: They were the first figurative art made by both our kids, somewhere between the ages of two and three, my children spread the fingers of one hand out across a piece of paper, and then with the help of a parent, traced their five fingers.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: I remember my son's face as he lifted his hand and looked absolutely shocked to see the shape of his hand, still on the paper, a semi-permanent record of himself.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: I am extremely happy that my children are no longer free, and yet to look at their little hands from those early artworks is to be inundated with a strange soul-splitting joy.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: Those pictures remind me that they are not just growing up, but also growing away from me, running toward their own lives.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: But of course, that's meaning I am applying to their hand stencils, and that complicated relationship between art and its viewers is never more fraught than when we are looking deeply into the past.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: In September of 1940, an 18-year-old mechanic named Marcel Ravi Dodd was walking his dog Robot in the countryside of southwestern France, when the dog disappeared down a hole.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: Robot eventually returned, but the next day, Ravi Dodd went to the spot with three friends to explore the hole.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: And after quite a bit of digging, they discovered a cave, with walls covered with paintings, including over 900 paintings of animals, horses, stags, bison, and also species that are now extinct, including a woolly rhinoceros.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: The paintings were astonishingly detailed and vivid, with red, yellow, and black paint made from pulverized mineral pigments that were usually blown through a narrow tube, possibly a hollowed bone onto the walls of the cave.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: It would eventually be established that these artworks were at least 17,000 years old.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: Two of the boys who visited the cave that day were so profoundly moved by the art they saw, that they camped outside the cave to protect it for over a year.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: After World War II, the French government took over a protection of the site, and the cave was open to the public in 1948.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: When Picasso saw the cave paintings on a visit that year, he reportedly said, we have invented nothing.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: There are many mysteries at Lescoe, why, for instance, are there no paintings of reindeer, which we know were the primary source of food for the Paleo-Withicumans who lived in that cave.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: Why were they so much more focused on painting animals than painting human forms?

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: Why are certain areas of the cave filled with images, including pictures on the ceiling that required the building of scaffolding to create, while other areas have only a few paintings?

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: And were the paintings spiritual, here are sacred animals, or were they practical?

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: Here is a guide to some of the animals that might kill you.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: Aside from the animals, there are nearly 1,000 abstract signs and shapes we cannot interpret, and also several negative hand stencils, as they are known by art historians.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: These are the paintings that most interest me.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: They were created by pressing one hand with fingers played against the wall of the cave, and then blowing pigment, leaving the area around the hand painted.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: Similar hand stencils have been found in caves around the world, from Indonesia to Spain to Australia to the Americas to Africa.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: We have found these memories of hands from 15 or 30 or even 40,000 years ago.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: These hand stencils remind us of how different life was in the distant past, and mutations likely from frostbite or common in Europe, and so you often see negative hand stencils with three or four fingers, and life was short and difficult, as many as a quarter of women died in childbirth, around 50% of children died before the age of five.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: But they also remind us that the humans of the past were as human as we are, their hands indistinguishable from hours.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: These communities hunted and gathered, and there were no large, caloric surpluses, so every healthy person would have had to contribute to the acquisition of food and water, and yet somehow they still made time to create art, almost as if art isn't optional for humans.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: We see all kinds of hands stenciled on cave walls, children, and adults, but almost always the fingers are spread, like my kids' hand stencils.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: I know Jungian, but it's fascinating and a little strange that so many paleolithic humans, who couldn't possibly have had any contact with each other, created the same paintings the same way, paintings that we are still making.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: But then again, what the lasco art means to me is likely very different from what it meant to the people who made it.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: Some academics theorize that the hand stencils were part of funding rituals, then there's always the possibility that the hand was just a convenient model situated at the end of the wrist.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: To me though, the hand stencils at lasco say, I was here, they say, you are not new, and because they are negative prints surrounded by red pigment, they also look to me like something out of a horror movie, like ghostly hands reaching up from some bloody background.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: They remind me that, as Alice Walker wrote, all history is current.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: The lasco cave has been closed to the public for many years now, too many contemporary humans breathing inside of it, led to the growth of mold and likens, which is damaged some of the art.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: Just the act of looking at something can ruin it, I guess.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: But tourists can still visit an imitation cave called lasco 2, in which the artwork has been meticulously recreated.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: Humans making fake cave art to save real cave art may feel like peak anthropocene behavior, but I have to confess that even though I am agitated and cynical semi-professional reviewer of human activity, I actually find it overwhelmingly hopeful that 14agers and a dog named Robot discovered a cave with 17,000 year old hand prints, that the cave was so overwhelmingly beautiful that two of those teenagers devoted themselves to its protection, and that when we humans became a danger to that cave's beauty, we agreed to stop going.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: Lasco is there, you cannot visit.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: You can go to the fake cave we've built, and see nearly identical hand stencils, but you will know this is not the thing itself, but a shadow of it.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: This is a hand print, but not a hand.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: This is a memory that you cannot return to, all of which makes the cave very much like the past it represents.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: We hope you enjoyed this video, even if it was different, check out John Green's podcast, the Anthropocene reviewed, where he poetically reviews the human world we live in.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: John is a good friend of course, because art, in fact, without his channel Crash Course, that he and his brother Hank started years ago, Kurt's Cazard would not exist, because it was the original inspiration for what we do today.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: And over the years, John and Hank have helped us in a multitude of ways from advice to just being friends.

Title: The Past We Can Never Return To – The Anthropocene Reviewed
Sentence: So check out the Anthropocene reviewed, or any of their many channels.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: At this very second, you are on a narrow ledge between life and death.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: You probably don't feel it, but there's an incredible amount of activity going on inside you.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: And this activity can never stop.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: Pick to yourself as a slinky falling down an escalator moving upwards.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: The falling part represents the self-replicating processes of yourselves.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: The escalator represents the laws of physics driving you forwards.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: To be alive is to be in motion but never arriving anywhere.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: If you reach the top of the escalator, there's no more falling possible and you are dead forever.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: Somewhat unsettlingly, the universe wants you to reach the top.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: How do you avoid that and why are you alive?

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: All life is based on the cell.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: A cell is a piece of the dead universe that separated itself from the rest so it could do its own thing for a while.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: When this separation breaks down, it dies and joins the rest of the dead universe again.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: Unfortunately, the universe would like for life to be done with doing its own thing.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: For some reason, it's not a fan of exciting things but tries to be as boring as possible.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: We call this principle entropy and it's a fundamental rule of our universe.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: It's pretty complicated and counter-intuitive so we'll explain it in detail in another video.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: For now, all you need to know is living things are inherently exciting.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: A cell is filled up with millions of proteins and millions more simpler molecules like water.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: Thousands of complex self-replicating processes are happening up to hundreds of thousands of times every second.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: To stay alive and exciting, it has to constantly work to keep itself from achieving entropy and becoming boring and dead.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: The cell has to maintain the separation from the rest of the universe.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: It's doing this, for example, by keeping the concentration of certain molecules different on the inside and the outside by actively pumping out excess molecules.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: To do stuff like this, a cell needs energy.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: Energy is the ability of things in the universe to do work, to move or manipulate a thing, to create change.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: This ability cannot be created or destroyed, the set amount of energy in the universe will never change.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: We don't know why, it just is that way.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: So billions of years ago, one of the most crucial challenges for the first living beings was to get usable energy.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: We don't know a lot about the first cells, except that they got their energy from simple chemical reactions.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: And they found the ultimate energy transfer system, the energetic building block of life.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: The molecule, a denocene, triphosphate or ATP.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: Its structure makes it uniquely good at accepting and releasing energy.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: When a cell needs energy, for example, to pump out molecules or to repair a broken micro machine, it can break down ATP and use the chemical energy to do work and create change.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: This is why living beings are able to do stuff.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: We don't know when or how exactly the first ATP molecule was made on Earth.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: But every living thing we know uses ATP or something very similar to keep its internal machinery running.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: It's crucial for almost every process plants, fungi, bacteria and animals need to survive.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: Without ATP, no life on Earth, possibly anywhere.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: While breaking down chemicals for energy is nice and all, early life did miss out on the greatest available source of energy, the Sun.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: The Sun.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: The Sun merges atoms and radiates photons away, the carry energy into the solar system.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: But this energy is raw and indigestible.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: It needs to be refined.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: After hundreds of millions of years of evolution, finally a cell figured out how to eat the Sun.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: It absorbed radiation and converted much of it into neat little chemical packages that it could use to stay alive.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: We call this process Photosynthesis.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: You take photons that are wobbly with electromagnetic energy and use a part of this energy to merge and combine different molecules together.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: The electromagnetic energy is converted into chemical energy stored in the ATP molecule.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: This process became even better as some cells learn to create better chemical packages, glucose or sugar.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: Easy to break down, high energy and pretty tasty.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: This is so convenient that some cells decided that instead of doing all that pesky photosynthesis work themselves, they would just swallow other cells that did and take their glucose and ATP.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: This is widely considered one of the biggest anime betrayals in evolutionary history.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: And so things went on.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: Photosynthesizing cells could mostly harness energy at their surfaces, which limited their maximum energy production, which limited their evolutionary avenue somewhat.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: So time passed.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: Some cells made sugar, others ate them.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: Evolution did its thing, but overall things stayed pretty much the same for hundreds of millions of years.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: Until one day, a cell ate another and did not kill it.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: Instead, they became one cell.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: Nothing had changed that day, but Earth would be different forever.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: This cell became the ancestor of all animals on this planet.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: Blue whales, amoeba, dinosaurs, jellyfish, pink fairy armadillos, and sun decolugos.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: And of course, you.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: All can trace back their existence to this moment.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: The merging of two living beings is so important because when those two cells became one, they became way more powerful.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: The formerly independent cell in the inside could stop trying to survive.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: It could concentrate on one thing, make ATP.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: It became the powerhouse of the cell, the first mitochondria.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: The host cells job became to ensure survival in the dangerous world and provide the mitochondria with food.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: mitochondria basically reverse photosynthesis in a similarly complex process.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: They take sugar molecules that we got from eating other living things, combust them with oxygen and precursor molecules to make new energy-rich ATP molecules.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: This process works like a tiny furnace and spits out waste products like CO2, water, and a little bit of kinetic energy that you experience as body heat.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: This first division of labor meant the new cell had way more energy available than any cell before, which meant more possibilities for evolution to enable more complex cells.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: At some point, these cells began to form small groups or communities, which led to multi cellular life and finally to you.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: Today, you are a pile of trillions of cells.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: Each filled with dozens, if not hundreds of little machines, the provide you with usable energy to stay alive.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: If this process is interrupted, even for a few minutes, you die.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: But if life is so fragile, wouldn't it be a good idea to store ATP?

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: Like we store sugar in our fat cells, so we don't die if we stop breathing for a while.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: If life has solved so many problems to make you live today, what's up with the dying quickly thing?

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: Even simple bacteria like E. coli make about 50 times their body weight in ATP for every cell division.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: Your trillions of cells need a lot of ATP to keep you around.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: Every day, your body produces and converts about 90 million billion molecules of ATP, about your own body weight.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: You need a whole person's worth of ATP just to make it through a single day.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: Even storing enough ATP to last you a few minutes is basically impossible.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: An ATP molecule is really good for shifting energy around quickly, but it's terrible for storage since it has only 1% of a glucose molecules energy at 3 times its mass.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: So ATP is constantly produced and used out fairly quickly.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: This was the short and simplified story of the molecule that allows you to be different from the dead universe and to be the slinky on the escalator.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: It is a weird story.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: There is this molecule you need to survive at all times.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: You need it to keep moving because even a short break brings your slinky to a stop.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: And you need to make it yourself.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: It's like driving a car at full speed while producing fuel in the trunk with junk that you pick up from the side of the road.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: As far as we know, this all began billions of years ago when tiny parts of the dead universe came together and became something else from moment.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: It could keep itself going.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: It could grow.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: That moment set the slinky in motion and it's been going ever since.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: From the very first cells to you watching this now.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: At some point you will merge with the rest of the dead universe again.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: Maybe you'll tell its stories about your adventures, maybe not.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: But before you find out, you get to do what life does best.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: Making a dead universe much more interesting.

Title: Why Are You Alive – Life, Energy & ATP
Sentence: If you are currently bored for whatever reason and you want to make your life more interesting, we've got something for you.

Sentence: Learning something while creating stuff for yourself is pretty fun and fulfilling.

Sentence: Just try something to improve your skills and at the same time fight them boredom of being stuck inside.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: In December 2019, the Chinese authorities notified the world that a virus was spreading through their communities.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: In the following months, it spread to other countries with cases doubling within days.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: This virus is the Savira Cute Respiratory Syndrome related coronavirus, too, the causes the disease called COVID-19 and that everyone's simply calls coronavirus.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: What actually happens when it infects a human and what should we all do?

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: A virus is really just a hull around genetic material and a few proteins arguably not even a living thing.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: It can only make more of itself by entering a living cell.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: Coronavirus-based spread via services, but it's still uncertain how long it can survive on them.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: It's main way of spreading seems to be droplet infection when people cough or if you touch someone who's ill and then you're face, say rubbing your eyes or nose.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: The virus starts its journey here and then it's as a still way deeper into the body.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: Its destinations are the intestines, the spleen or the lungs where it can have the most dramatic effect.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: Even just a few coronaviruses can cause quite a dramatic situation.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: The lungs are lined with billions of epithelial cells.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: These are the border cells of your body lining your organs and mucosa waiting to be infected.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: Corona connects to a specific receptor on its victims' membranes to inject its genetic material.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: The cell, ignorant of what's happening, executes the new instructions which are pretty simple, copy and reassemble.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: It fills up with more and more copies of the original virus until it reaches a critical point and receives one final order, self-destruct.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: The cell sort of melts away releasing new coronavirus ready to attack more cells.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: The number of infected cells grows exponentially.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: After about 10 days, millions of body cells are infected and billions of viruses swore the lungs.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: The virus has not caused too much damage yet, but Corona is now going to release a real beast on you, your own immune system.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: The immune system, while there to protect you, can actually be pretty dangerous to yourself and needs tight regulation.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: And as immune cells pour into the lungs to fight the virus, Corona infects some of them and creates confusion.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: Cells have neither ears nor eyes, they communicate mostly via tiny information proteins called cytokines, nearly every important immune reaction is controlled by them.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: Corona causes infected immune cells to overreact and yellow bloody murder.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: In a sense, it puts the immune system into a fighting frenzy and sends way more soldiers than it should, wasting its resources and causing damage.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: Two kinds of cells in particular wreak havoc.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: First, neutrophiles which are greater killing stuff, including ourselves.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: As they arrive in their thousands, they start pumping out enzymes that destroy as many friends as enemies.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: The other important type of cells that go into a frenzy are killer T-cells, which usually order infected cells to commit controlled suicide.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: Confused as they are, they start ordering healthy cells to kill themselves too.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: The more and more immune cells arrive, the more damage they do, and the more healthy lung tissue they kill.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: This might get so bad that it can cause permanent irreversible damage that leads to lifelong disabilities.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: In most cases, the immune system slowly regains control.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: It kills the infected cells, intercepts the viruses trying to infect new ones, and cleans up the battlefield.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: Recovery begins.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: The majority of people infected by Corona will get through it with relatively mild symptoms.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: But many cases become severe or even critical.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: We don't know the percentage because not all cases have been identified, but it's safe to say that there is a lot more than with the flu.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: In more severe cases, millions of epithelial cells have died, and with them the lungs protective lining is gone.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: That means that the alveoli, tiny air-sax via which breathing occurs, can be infected by bacteria that aren't usually a big problem.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: Patients get pneumonia, respiration becomes hard or even fails, and patients need ventilators to survive.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: The immune system has fought at full capacity for weeks and made millions of antiviral weapons, and as thousands of bacteria rapidly multiply, it is overwhelmed.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: They enter the blood and overrun the body.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: If this happens, death is very likely.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: The coronavirus is often compared to the flu, but actually it's much more dangerous.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: While the exact death rate is hard to pin down during an ongoing pandemic, we know for sure that it's much more contagious and spread faster than the flu.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: There are two futures for a pandemic like corona, fast and slow.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: Which future we will see depends on how we all react to it in the early days of the outbreak.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: A fast pandemic will be horrible and cost many lives.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: A slow pandemic will not be remembered by the history books.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: The worst case scenario for a fast pandemic begins with a very rapid rate of infection because there are no countermeasures in place to slow it down.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: Why is this so bad?

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: In a fast pandemic, many people get sick at the same time.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: If the numbers get too large, healthcare systems become unable to handle it.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: There aren't enough resources like medical staff or equipment like ventilators left to help everybody.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: People will die untreated.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: And as more healthcare workers get sick themselves, the capacity of healthcare systems falls even further.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: If this becomes the case, then horrible decisions will have to be made about who gets to live and who doesn't.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: The number of deaths rises significantly in such a scenario.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: To avoid this, the world, that means all of us, needs to do what it can to turn this into a slow pandemic.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: A pandemic is slowed down by the right responses, especially in the early phase, so that everyone who gets sick can get treatment and there's no crunch point with overwhelmed hospitals.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: Since we don't have a vaccine for corona, we have to socially engineer our behaviour to act like a social vaccine.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: This simply means two things.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: Not getting infected and not infecting others.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: Although it sounds trivial, the very best thing you can do is to wash your hands.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: Soap is actually a powerful tool.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: The coronavirus is encased in what is basically a layer of fat.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: Soap breaks that fat apart and leaves it unable to infect you.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: It also makes your hands slippery and with the mechanical motions of washing viruses are ripped away.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: To do it properly, wash your hands as if you've just cut up some jalapenos and want to put in your contacts next.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: The next thing is social distancing, which is not a nice experience, but a nice thing to do.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: This means no hugging, no handshakes.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: If you can stay at home, stay at home to protect those who need to be out for society to function.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: From doctors to cashiers or police officers.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: You depend on all of them.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: They all depend on you to not get sick.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: On a larger level, there are quarantines, which can mean different things from travel restrictions or actual orders to stay at home.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: quarantines are not great to experience and certainly not popular, but they buy us and especially the researchers working on medication and vaccination crucial time.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: So if you are put under quarantine, you should understand why and respect it.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: None of this is fun, but looking at the big picture, it is a really small price to pay.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: The question of how pandemics end depends on how they start.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: If they start fast with a steep slope, they end badly.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: If they start slow with a not so steep slope, they end okish.

Title: The Coronavirus Explained & What You Should Do
Sentence: And in this day age, it really is in all of our hands.

Sentence: Literally and figuratively.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Cancer is a creepy and mysterious thing.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: In the process of trying to understand it to get better at killing it, we discovered a biological paradox that remains unsolved to this day.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Large animals seem to be immune to cancer, which doesn't make any sense.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: The bigger a being, the more cancer it should have.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: To understand why, we first need to take a look at the nature of cancer itself.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Our cells are protein robots made out of hundreds of millions of parts.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Guided only by chemical reactions, they create and dismantle structures, sustain a metabolism to gain energy, or make almost perfect copies of themselves.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: We call these complex chemical reactions pathways.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: They are biochemical networks upon networks, intertwined and stamped on top of each other.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Most of them can barely be comprehended by a single human mind, and yet they function perfectly.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Until they don't.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: With billions of trillions of reactions happening in thousands of networks over many years, the question is not if something will go wrong, but when.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Tiny mistakes add up until the grandiose machinery gets corrupted.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: To prevent this from getting out of hand, our cells have kills, which is that make them commit so a size.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: But these kill switches are not infallible.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: If they fail, a cell can turn into a cancer cell.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Most of them are slain by the immune system very quickly.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: But this is a numbers game.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Given enough time, a cell will accrue enough mistakes, slip by unnoticed and begin making more of itself.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: All animals have to deal with this problem.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: In general, the cells of different animals are the same size.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: The cells of a mouse aren't smaller than yours.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: It just has fewer cells in total and a shorter lifespan.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Fewer cells and a short life means a lower chance of things going wrong or cells mutating, or at least it should mean that.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Humans live about 50 times longer and have 1,000 times more.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Yet the rate of cancer is basically the same in humans and in mice.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Even wager, blue whales with about 3,000 times more cells than humans don't seem to get cancer at all, really.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: This is Peto's paradox.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: The baffling realization that large animals have much, much less cancer than they should.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Scientists think there are two main ways of explaining the paradox, evolution and hyperchumers.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Solution 1, Evolve or become a blob of cancer.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: As multicellular beings developed to 600 million years ago, animals became bigger and bigger, which added more and more cells and hence more and more chances that cells could be corrupted.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: So the collective had to invest in better and better cancer defenses.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: The ones that did not died out.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: But cancer doesn't just happen, but it's a process that involves many individual mistakes and mutations in several specific genes within the same cell.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: These genes are called proto-onca genes and when they mutate it's bad news.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: For example, with the right mutation, a cell will lose its ability to kill itself.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Another mutation and it will develop the ability to hide.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Another and it will send out calls for resources.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Another one and it will multiply quickly.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: These oncogenes have an antagonist though, tumour suppressor genes.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: They prevent these critical mutations from happening or order the cell to kill itself if they decided to be on repair.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: It turns out that large animals have an increased number of them.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Because of this, an infant cells require more mutations than mice cells to develop a tumour.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: They are not immune but more resilient.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: This adaption probably comes with a cost in some form, but researchers still aren't sure what it is.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Maybe tumour suppressors make elephants age quicker later in life or slow down how quickly injures heal.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: We don't know yet.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: But the solution to the paradox may actually be something different.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Hypertumors.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Solution 2.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Hypertumors.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Yes.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Rally.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Hypertumors are named after hyperparacites, the parasites of parasites.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Hypertumors are the tumours of tumours.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Cancer can be thought of as a breakdown in cooperation.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Normally, cells work together to form structures like organs, tissue or elements of the immune system.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: But cancer cells are selfish and only work for their own short-term benefit.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: If they're successful, they form tumours, huge cancer collectives that can be very hard to kill.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Making a tumour is hard work though.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Millions or billions of cancer cells mod apply rapidly, which requires a lot of resources and energy.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: The amount of nutrients they can steal from the body becomes the limiting factor for growth.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: So the tumour cells trick the body to build new blood vessels directly to the tumour to feed the thing, killing it.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: And here, the nature of cancer cells may become their own undoing.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Cancer cells are inherently unstable and so they can continue to mutate.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Some of them faster than their bodies.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: If they do this for a while, at some point, one of the copies of the copies of the original cancer cell might suddenly think of itself as an individual again and stop cooperating.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Which means, just like the body, the original tumour suddenly becomes an enemy, fighting for the same scarce nutrients and resources.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: So the newly mutated cells can create a hyperchumour.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Instead of helping, they cut off the blood supply to their former bodies, which will starve and kill the original cancer cells.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Cancer is killing cancer.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: This process can repeat over and over, and this may prevent cancer from becoming a problem for a large organism.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: It is possible that large animals have more of these hyperchumers than we realize they might just not become big enough to notice.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Which makes sense, a 2 gram tumour is 10% of a mouse's body weight, while it's less than 0.002% of a human, and 0.00002% of a blue whale.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: All three tumours require the same number of cell divisions and have the same number of cells.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: So an old blue whale might be filled with tiny cancers and just not care.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: There are other proposed solutions to Peter's paradox, such as different metabolic rates or different cellular architecture.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: But right now, we just don't know.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Scientists are working on the problem.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Figuring out how large animals are so resilient to one of the most deadly diseases we know could open the path to new therapies and treatments.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Cancer has always been a challenge.

Title: Why Blue Whales Don't Get Cancer - Peto's Paradox
Sentence: Today, we are finally beginning to understand it and by doing so, one day, we might finally overcome it.

Sentence: Nuration.
