Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: Human history is told by the energy we use.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: And first we had to use our muscles, then we learned to control fire.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: We industrialized the world using coal and oil, and entered the atomic age when we learned how to split a nucleus.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: At each step we increased our energy harvest to a scale never seen before, and advanced as a species.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: Currently, we're slowly transitioning to renewables, and if we're lucky, fusion energy will become viable in the future.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: As humanity progresses further, if we don't destroy ourselves, or our habitat, we will likely gain complete control of our planet's resources.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: At that stage, we'll probably begin to look outwards for new places to expand into.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: But space is hard, and establishing a serious human presence in the solar system will require ungodly amounts of energy.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: Luckily, we know where to find a way to get to the planet's energy.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: We know where to find it.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: The Sun, the ultimate source of energy.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: A furnace 100 quintillion times more powerful than our most efficient nuclear reactor.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: It shines with the energy of a trillion nuclear bombs per second.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: So how do we get this energy?

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: Not some of it.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: All of it.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: If we want to collect the most energy physically possible, we'll have to build the largest most ambitious structure in the universe.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: The Dyson sphere, a mega structure that encompasses a whole star to capture its power output.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: For an intelligent species, building a Dyson sphere is a technological leap on a par with the discovery of fire for our ancestors.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: The transition from a planetary species to an interstellar species.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: It would usher in an age of exploration and expansion on a scale we can barely imagine.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: So what would it look like?

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: A solid shell enveloping the Sun is probably not the way to go.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: A large rigid body like that would be vulnerable to impacts, possibly shattering.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: It would be liable to drift and could crash straight into the Sun.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: A more viable design for a Dyson sphere might be a Dyson swarm, an enormous set of orbiting panels that collect the Sun's power and beam it elsewhere.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: Such a swarm would give humanity basically unlimited energy.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: The building it won't be easy.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: The Sun is very big, so we need a lot of satellites.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: If each satellite is a square kilometer, we'd need around 30-cortillion to surround the Sun.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: Even if their built is likely as possible, we need about 100 quintillion tons of material.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: And then we need the energy to actually put the parts together and deliver them to their positions around the Sun.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: On top of all that, we need to have a permanent infrastructure set up in space to start building.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: Let's assume for the purposes of this video that our descendants will take care of that and want to create the mega structure.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: We can sort the challenges into three main categories, materials, design and energy.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: To get the vast amounts of raw materials required for our Dyson swarm, we'll have to largely disassemble a whole planet.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: Of the planet's available, Mercury is the best candidate.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: It's the closest to the Sun and very metal-rich.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: Closed of the Sun also means less moving stuff around.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: And Mercury has no atmosphere and only about a third of the surface gravity of Earth, making it comparatively easy to launch material into space.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: Next, we should consider the design of our swarm.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: Simpler is better.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: Conventional solar panels are far too intricate and short-lived.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: Our satellites need to operate without repairs or intervention for astronomical long times, and they need to be cheap to produce.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: They're most likely going to be enormous mirrors, which refer to sunlight to central collecting stations, like in concentrated solar power on Earth.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: To build and launch them efficiently, they must be incredibly light, made of little more than polished metal foil bound to some supports.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: And last, we need the energy to build and launch the swarm itself.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: Taking a part of planet and launching things into space requires an enormous amount of energy.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: For example, if we used all the fossil fuels and uranium on Earth, and we were perfectly efficient, we could only launch as much mass as Mount Everest into space.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: A rather meager accomplishment compared to planetary disassembly.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: To get the energy needed to build a dyson sphere, it's almost as if you're going to need the power output of a dyson sphere.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: But that's okay.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: There's plenty of sunlight to be had on Mercury, so let's get to work.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: Humans are expensive to keep alive and are very sensitive to the environment, so we'd want to automate as much as possible.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: Ideally, we'd have a small crew of controllers who oversee an army of autonomous machines doing the actual work.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: There are four major pieces of technology required.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: Solar collectors, miners, refiners, and launch equipment.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: The solar collectors are going to give us the energy we need to disassemble the planet.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: To start, maybe we'd deploy something like one square kilometer of them, either as mirrors or as traditional solar panels.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: They'll provide the energy to run our miners, which strip mine the surface of the planet, and our refiners, which extract valuable elements and fabricate them into our swarm satellites.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: To get them into space, we need a creative and efficient solution.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: Rockets are too expensive and difficult to deal with and reuse.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: Instead, we'll want to use a sort of rail gun, a long electromagnetic track, which launches our satellites at high speeds.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: Our swarm satellites will be packed tight for launch, unfurling like an enormous origami once in orbit.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: From this point, we can take advantage of exponential growth, using the energy of the existing parts of the swarm to build more infrastructure on Mercury, and launch new panels faster and faster.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: Each panel provides the energy to build another.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: Those two work together to build the next two.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: Four become eight, eight become 16, and so on.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: Within just about 60 doubling times, the Sun would be completely surrounded by solar panels.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: And this can happen quickly.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: If a square kilometer of solar collectors takes a month to build, we could be done in a decade.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: If only our infrastructure on the planet's surface can keep up with the quirky grown budget of energy.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: Even collecting 1% of the Sun's energy is an unbelievable change in our species, energy budget.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: We could create the infrastructure to be basically unlimited amounts of energy around the solar system for all sorts of projects.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: Colonies on other worlds, terraforming planets, constructing more mega structures, or even travelling to other stars.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: It could be the start of an interstellar civilization.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: Based on physics alone, this is not just possible, but easy.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: It's such a simple process and such a necessary step for any space.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: We step for any species to expand beyond their home planet, that many astronomers think there are probably Dyson spheres already out there in the Milky Way.

Title: How to Build a Dyson Sphere - The Ultimate Megastructure
Sentence: We haven't spotted any yet, but they could be there.

Sentence: It's far from certain that humanity will ever get to this point.

Sentence: Our attention is too often focused on short-term political gains and conflicts that will not matter in the long-wrap.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: Space Travel is the most exciting and challenging adventure humanity has ever undertaken.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: But in an irony of history, we may stop ourselves from going into space the more we do it.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: With every rocket launched and with every satellite deployed, we're creating a trap for ourselves that gets deadlier and more dangerous every year.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: If it's ever activated, it could end the space age and trap us on our planet for decades or even centuries.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: Getting something into space is incredibly hard.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: To do so, you need to move very very fast, at first straight up to leave the atmosphere, then sideways to be going to sort of circling around the earth, still very very fast.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: If you do that successfully, you can enter a low earth orbit.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: And once in orbit, it's very hard to get out of orbit.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: Unless you have energy to spare, you're sort of locked in here falling around the earth forever.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: That's great for things we want to stay up, like space stations and satellites, and so we move the majority of humanity's space infrastructure to this place, just a few hundred kilometres above the surface.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: Just high enough so that the atmosphere is so thin that orbiting things can stay up for centuries before air resistance can slow them enough to bring the back to earth.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: But this is also the source of our deadly trap.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: Rockets are really metal cylinders that keep big paths of fuel in place.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: Whenever a portion of the fuel has been spent, the empty tanks are dropped to make the rocket lighter.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: Some parts crashed down to earth or burn up in the atmosphere.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: But most of the useless rocket parts stay up and begin to orbit the planet.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: After decades of space travel, low earth orbit is a junkyard of spent boosters, broken satellites and millions of pieces of shrapnel from missile tests and explosions.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: Right now, we know of around 2,600 defunct satellites, 10,000 objects bigger than a monitor, 20,000 does large snap-all, 500,000 pieces the size of a marble, and at least 100 million parts so small they can't be tracked.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: This debris is moving its speeds of up to 30,000 kilometres per hour, circling earth on criss-crossing orbits multiple times a day.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: Orbital speeds are so fast that being hit by debris the size of a pea is like being shot by a plasma gun.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: On impact the debris vaporizes, releasing enough energy to punch holes straight through solid metal.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: So, we've covered the space around our planet with millions of deadly pieces of destruction.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: And we also put a trillion dollar global infrastructure network right in the danger zone.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: It performs critical duties essential to the modern world, global communication.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: GPS and navigation.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: Collecting weather data, looking out for asteroids and all manner of scientific discoveries.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: Things we would miss very much if they suddenly went away.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: If just one piece size bullet hits one of our 1,100 working satellites, it will be destroyed instantly.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: Three or four satellites are already being destroyed this way every year.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: As the number of satellites and the amount of junk in orbit is expected to grow tenfold in the next decade, we're approaching a tipping point.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: But the worst thing in space is not tiny pieces of junk.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: The worst thing would be an unstoppable chain reaction that turns a lot of non-junct things into junk.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: For example, if two satellites hit each other in just the right way.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: If satellites collide, they don't stop and fall out of the sky.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: It's more of a splash for the crash.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: Orpital speeds are so fast, solid pieces spray right through each other, transforming the two satellites into clouds of thousands of little things, still fast enough to destroy more satellites.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: This could trigger the slowest and most destructive sort of domino effect, a collision cascade.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: Like a shotgun spray, each collision creates more bullets.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: What was once a single tiny target, very unlikely to hit anything, becomes a wall of destruction, hungry to make more.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: As more and more satellites are destroyed, the destruction accelerates exponentially, eventually destroying everything parked in orbit.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: But space is very empty, so the first few collisions may take a long time.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: By the time we realize what's happening, it's too late.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: One year, one satellite is destroyed, and that's no big deal.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: The next year, five.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: The year after, 50, until there's nothing left.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: The situation in orbit is rapidly worsening, and we may already be past the point of no return.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: Within 10 years, space around Earth may no longer be viable for long-term satellites or rockets.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: The worst case scenario is horrifying.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: A debris field made of hundreds of millions of pieces, many too small to track, moving at 30,000 kilometers per hour.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: It would effectively create a deadly barrier around Earth, possibly too dangerous to cross.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: Dreams of moon bases, Mars, Colonies, or Space Travel at all may be set back centuries.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: And the loss of our space infrastructure would send some of the technology we rely on daily back to the 1970s.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: But it might not be too late to clean up our mess.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: While the space industry has become better at avoiding space junk, it's still growing fast and occasional weapon tests don't help.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: So, there have been a couple of wild but also serious suggestions about how to quickly remove as much deadly space junk as possible, without creating more in the process.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: Lots of ideas are being thrown around, and some of the most seriously considered, involve capture and return missions which are being tested now.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: One method involves meeting a piece of junk in orbit with a small satellite loaded with a net.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: Once caught, a small rocket could be used to bring it down towards Earth.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: Target's too large for a net might be instead caught with a harpoon on a tether.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: Instead of firing a rocket, the cleaner would deploy a large sail to reduce atmospheric drag and accelerate orbital decay.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: And there are lots of other wild sci-fi sounding proposals too.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: Some might use giant electromagnets.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: These magnetic tugs work by pushing on the magnetic components in sight satellites that they use to stabilize and orientate themselves in Earth's magnetic fields.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: These may be safer and more reliable than nets and harpoons, because they never have to make contact with the junk they're handling, so there's no risk of accidentally breaking up their target into more junk.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: As for the tiniest bits of junk, lasers might be the key to vaporizing them entirely.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: Satellites with lasers wouldn't need to visit their targets, they can shoot them from far away.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: Large objects can't exactly be shot down, but lasers can be used to oblate them, or burn tiny amounts of material off the site to push the junk to a safer orbit.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: Whatever technology we use at the end, we better start doing something soon.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: Before 100 million bullets become a trillion and the trap is set.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: If we don't act, our adventure in space might end before it's even begun.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: If our days of dreaming about space exploration might be numbered anyway, we better put them to good use.

Title: End of Space – Creating a Prison for Humanity
Sentence: One of the things we'd most like to spend our time on is learning more about our universe, and to do that, you can just keep watching.

Sentence: Kurzgesarthe has worked with Brilliant for a bit, and we love how they teach you science and maths in a practical way, by guiding you through problems step by step, so you can actually understand the concepts behind them.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: A lot of things can be beautiful, landscapes, faces, fine art, or epic architecture, stars in the sky.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Or simply the reflection of the sun on an empty bottle.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Beauty is nothing tangible, it only exists in our heads as a pleasant feeling.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: If we have to define it, we perceive something as beautiful if it's colour, shape, for more proportion somehow are appealing or delightful to us.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Beauty is a very human experience that's been with us for millions of years.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Even our first tools were trimmed to a symmetrical shape.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Researchers have tried to find practical reasons why our ancestors invested the time to make their tools look nice, but couldn't really identify any.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: It seems that early humans shaped their tools into tear drops simply because they like them better that way.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Throughout our history, the definition of beauty has changed a lot.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Ideals have shifted or turned into their opposites.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: But beyond individual and contemporary tastes, some things have never really gone out of fashion.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: The golden ratio, symmetry or fractal patterns can be found in the art and architecture of cultures from our beginnings to today.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Humans seem to be in mysterious inherent agreement about the beauty of certain things.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: The patterns that keep coming up are all rooted in nature.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: They became part of our biology because they helped our ancestors survive.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Prental patterns, for example, occur all over nature in snail shells, flower heads, waves or clouds.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Identifying and assessing these things and phenomena correctly used to be vital.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Devote clouds being rain will come soon.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Are these waters safe to swim through?

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Can I eat this?

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Another pervasive thing is symmetry.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: In nature it means everything is as it should be.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Stems and trees and leaves and blossoms all grow symmetrically.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: A deer with impressive antlers is probably a source of nutritious meat.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: A deformed wheat here may not be safe to eat.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: A symmetrical face is more likely to belong to a healthy and fertile mating partner.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Because symmetry is so common in form and forer, it's extremely familiar to our brain.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: It helped our ancestors evaluate their environment more easily and react quickly to danger.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Things that help us survive activate the rewards centre in our brain, Recognizing signals of safety and nutrition trigger nice feelings in us.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: So our sense of beauty probably evolved from pattern recognition.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: But it goes way beyond that now.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Humans seem to have evolved and instinct for beauty.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: An instinct for beauty that is deeply hardwired into us.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: It remains even after other processes in our brains are working.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Our timers patients were asked to rank the beauty of several paintings.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Then the experiment was repeated two weeks later.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: The patients had long since forgotten the paintings, but still ranked the beauty of the paintings in the same order.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: One could argue that this doesn't say much, so what if people stick to their personal preferences?

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: But other research has shown that we have a sort of lowest common denominator when it comes to beauty.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: In different experiments, people were asked to distinguish real from fake abstract paintings.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Some were originals by Mondrian and Pollock that were painted based on strict rules like fractal patterns, while the imitations were not.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: The majority picked out the original artworks.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: This worked with paintings from both artists, even though their styles are very different.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Another experiment also used abstract artworks, but asked people to pick them out among similar paintings made either by children or animals.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Again, the test subjects pointed out that legit paintings whose patterns were carefully planned and not random.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: So while we have a hard time pinning down what beauty is or what is based on, we somehow recognise it when we see it.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Humans don't navigate nature trying to survive day by day anymore.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: We left the natural world behind and created our own.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: We made the objects that surround us, the things we wear and use and look at.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: As we spread over the planet and our numbers grew, we shaped a completely man-made environment.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: In the process of doing so, we often neglected beauty and favor of functionality, cost or efficiency.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: We built rows and rows of concrete housing blocks that nobody wants to live in.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: We have ugly underground subway stations, Shabby Public Service Buildings and sprawling malls.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: One bland standardized box beside the next.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Humans don't like monotony, eye tracking software has shown that people keep focusing on details and ornaments of architecture while brushing quickly over blank walls.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: And not only are they no fun to look at, they actually make us miserable.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Experiments with skin sensors showed that looking at vast dull facade makes us feel bored and uncomfortable.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: This kind of boredom has been linked to raised heart rates and stress levels, and the opposite seems to be true too.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Over the last decades, more and more studies have found that surroundings that are actually aesthetically pleasing to us can improve our well-being, our behaviour, cognitive function and mood.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Our body's end-brains react measureably and visibly to everything that surrounds us.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Beauty in particular has such a strong impact on our well-being that making useful things beautiful can actually make them better.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: In 2017, a hospital examined recovery factors through observation and interviews with patients and found that visual art in their lounge areas made them more comfortable and happier about their stay in general.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Another study looked at how well patients recovered in a hospital that had two wards.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: A very old and rather ugly one, and a newly renovated ward.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: To the researchers surprised the patients that stayed in the new renovated environment needed less pain medication and were released on average two days earlier than patients recovering in the old ward.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: More beautiful surroundings made them feel better physically.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Beauty also has an effect on us on a daily basis, it can improve our general happiness.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: A study that looked at the main factors influencing the happiness of adults revealed and unexpected result, besides things like good health and a harmonious family life, individual happiness is affected by how beautiful you find the city you live in.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Beauty scored even higher than cleanliness or safety.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: So, what can we learn from all of this?

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: We know that we humans have been fine-tuned for millions of years to process visual input and assess our surroundings.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: It's just what we're programmed to do, and we're starting to learn more about how much beauty as a property is really influencing us.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Beauty meets an inherent need for meaningful information.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: Maybe it would be worth giving it more space in this man-made world we have created.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: This video was a collaboration with the creative agency Zardmeister and Worsh as a contribution to their upcoming beauty exhibition.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: The exhibition will be shown at the Mark Vienna from October 23rd, 2018 until March 31st, 2019, and the Mark Frankfurt from May 1st until September 30, 2019.

Title: Why Beautiful Things Make us Happy – Beauty Explained
Sentence: If you want to learn more about the impact of beauty and sea tons of gorgeous installations and multimedia objects, go check it out.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Humans love meat.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Steak, fried chicken, bacon, pork belly and sausages are just the best things.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Eating meat has become so trivial that many people don't consider something a proper meal if there's no animal involved, which is pretty amazing since only a few decades ago meat was a luxury product.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Today you can get a cheeseburger for a dollar.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Paradoxically, meat is pretty much the most inefficient way of feeding humans.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: If we look at it on a global scale, our meaty diet is literally eating up the planet.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Why is that?

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: And what can we do about it without giving up steak?

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Humans keep a lot of animals for food.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Currently about 23 billion chickens, 1.5 billion cattle and roughly 1 billion pigs in sheep.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: That's a lot of mouths to feed, so we've transformed Earth into a giant feeding ground.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: 83% of its farmland is used for livestock, for example as pasture and farm fodder crops like corn and soy.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: That's 26% of Earth's total land area.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: If we include the water we need for these plants, meat and dairy production accounts for 27% of global freshwater consumption.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Unfortunately, meat production is like a black hole for resources.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Since animals are living things, most of their food is used to keep them alive while they grow their tasty parts.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Only a fraction of the nutrients from fodder crops end up in the meat we buy in the end.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Now, for example, convert only about 4% of the proteins and 3% of the calories of the plants we feed to them into beef.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: More than 97% of the calories are lost to us.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: To create one kilogram of steak, a cow needs to eat up to 25 kilos of grain and uses up to 15,000 liters of water.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Animal products are gusling up tons of food, but they only make up 18% of the calories humans eat.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: According to projections, we could nourish an additional 3.5 billion people if we just ate the stuff we feed to animals.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: To make our favorite food group even more unsustainable, about 15% of all greenhouse gas emissions caused by humans are created by the meat industry, as much as by all ships, planes, trucks and cars combined.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: And there's another aspect to meat.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: It comes from actual living beings.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Bigs, cattle and chicken, and one of the ones writing the history books, but if they were, humans would appear as rampant genocidal maniacs that thrive on suffering.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Globally, we kill about 200 million animals every day, about 74 billion a year.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: This means that every one and a half years, we kill more animals than people have lived in the entire 200,000 year history of humanity.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: When the could argue that we're doing them a favor, after all, they wouldn't exist without us.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: We might eat them in the end, but we also provide food and shelter and the gift of existence to them.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Unfortunately, we're not very nice gods.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: A lot of our meat comes from factory farms, huge industrial systems that house thousands of animals.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Engineer to be as efficient as possible, they have little regard for things like quality of life.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Most pigs are raised in gigantic windowless sheds and never get to see the sun.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Sows are kept in pens to small to turn around, where they give birth to one litter of piglets after another until it's their turn to be turned into bacon.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Dairy cows are forced to breathe continually to ensure their milk supply, but are separated from their calves' hours after birth.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: To fasten up beef cattle for slaughter, they're put in feedlots, confined pens where they can't roam and put on weight more quickly.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: To make it possible to keep them so tightly together without dying of diseases, the majority of antibiotics we use are for livestock, up to 80% in the US, which helps in the short term, but also fuels antibiotic resistances.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: But the ones that may have got the worst deal are chickens.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: In factory farms, they're kept in such vast numbers and so close to each other that they can't form the social structures they have in nature, so they start attacking each other.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: To stop that, we cut their beaks and claws.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Male chickens are deemed worthless since they can't lay eggs and are not suitable for meat production, so within minutes after birth, they're usually gased and shredded in grinders.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Several hundred million baby chickens are killed this way each year.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Even if you had a personal score to settle with chickens, how we treat them is beyond broken.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: So, better by organic meat where animals are treated nicely right?

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Organic farming regulations are designed to grind animals a minimum of comfort.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: The problem is that organic is an elastic term.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: According to EU regulations, an organic hen still might share one square meter of space with five others.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: That's a long way off from happy farm yard chickens.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Farms that sincerely do their best do exist of course, but meat is still a business, an organic label is a way to charge more money and countless scandals have revealed producers looking for ways to cheat the system.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: And while organic meat might be less cruel, it needs even more resources than conventional meat production.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: So buying organic is still preferable, but does not grant you moral absolute.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: The truth is, if suffering were a resource, we would create billions of tons of it per year.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: With the way we treat animals, we'll probably be one of the things future generations will look down on in this guest.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: While all these things are true, something else is true too.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Steak is amazing.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Burgers are the best food.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Chicken wings taste great.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Meat satisfies something buried deep in our lizard brain.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: We hardly ever see how our meat is made, we just eat it and love it.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: It creates joy, it brings us together for family meals and barbecue parties.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Eating meat doesn't make you a bad person, not eating meat doesn't make you a good one.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Life is complicated and so is the world we've created.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: So how should we deal with the fact that meat is extremely unsustainable and a sort of horrible torture?

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: For now, the easiest option is opting out more often.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Taking a meat-free day per week already makes a difference.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: If you want to eat meat produced with less suffering, try to buy from trusted producers with a good track record, even if it costs more.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: To make an impact on the environment, go for chicken and pig rather than lamb and beef, as they convert their feed more efficiently into meat.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: And if you're going to have your steak, you should eat it too.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: An average American throws out nearly a pound of food per day, a lot of which is meat.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: In the future, science could get us clean meat.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: Various startups have successfully grown meat in labs and are working on doing so on a commercial scale.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: But solutions like this are still a few years away.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: For now, enjoy your steak, but also respect it.

Title: Why Meat is the Best Worst Thing in the World 🍔
Sentence: And if you can, make it something special again.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: Humans dream about leaving Earth and traveling through the galaxy, but we were born too early to be part of it.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: Or were we?

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: The reality is we could begin our dream by building a moon-laced day.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: We actually do have the technology and current estimates from NASA and the private sector say it could be done for $22,40 billion spread out over about a decade.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: The price is comparable to the International Space Station or the budget surplus of Germany in 2017.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: Not that big an investment, really.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: The payoff would be a measurable.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: The moon is a sandbals to develop new technologies and exploit unlimited resources.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: It would start a new space race and lay the foundation for us to spread out into the solar system and beyond.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: It would create a vast array of new technologies to benefit us on Earth.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: And we would all be part of it.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: So why aren't we doing it?

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: Well, sadly, it's hard to get governments interested in long-term investments in the future of humanity.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: Let's imagine just doing it.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: If we start today, how would we build a moon base?

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: Throughout history, colonization happened in phases.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: In the first phase of the age of exploration of the new world, for example, European monarchs funded expeditions to chart and discover and to stake their claims.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: They planted a flag and set up a camp, but they didn't stay.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: In the second phase, small missions set up outposts and settlements were founded, which were still very dependent on their home countries for supplies.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: Some failed, but others survived and established a permanent presence.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: Only then, in the third phase, did a true colony form to which tradesmen and labourers could emigrate, creating new well-fanned opportunities for themselves and their families, sending extreme wealth back to their countries of origin.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: When we colonize the moon, we'll go through the same three phases.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: This time, without murdering millions of innocent people in the process.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: The moon is not a welcoming place for living things.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: A moon day lasts 29th days, with a difference of nearly 300 degrees Celsius between sunlight and shade.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: There's no atmosphere to shield us from meteorites, big and small or cosmic radiation.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: We're still, the lunar surface is covered in a layer of nasty jagged dust.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: The moon is hard, but we're good at doing hard things.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: In the first phase of lunar colonization, Eric Sporers proved it can be done, but a new world can be reached.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: This phase started 60 years ago with the Apollo missions.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: Since then, satellites like the American lunar reconnaissance orbiter have mapped the moon, while renvers like the Chinese YouTube have studied the composition of the lunar surface, looking for water ice and metals.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: Phase 1 is more or less complete.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: We know what we need to know to end a phase 2.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: In the second phase, astronauts will build the first moon base, and this could begin today.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: The first small moon base could be completed in a decade.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: The first nation that establishes this base will be akin to the first nation's building outposts in the new world 500 years ago.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: It's expensive to send rockets to the moon, so we will send as little as possible.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: The base will be light, little more than inflatable habitats for crews of no more than 12, and will be deployed somewhere with natural shelter.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: Options include caves like underground lava tube tunnels or craters near the poles, where the days are six months long.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: These astronauts will not stay long.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: The habitats is likely to be abandoned between missions as solar panels cannot generate electricity during the lunar night, but they'll do the groundwork to enable humans to stay permanently.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: Our first crew will consist of scientists and engineers who will study the composition of the moon, and whose experiments will explore ways of using the available lunar material, say purifying lunar ice and turning it into water for human use, and water is important for far more than drinking.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: They can use it to experiment with growing plants for food.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: Hydrogen fuel cells will store power through the long night extending astral states.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: And most importantly, it can be split into hydrogen and oxygen, rocket fuel.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: By harvesting water from the moon and putting it into orbit, the moon base will supply an orbital depot, where scientific missions to Mars and the outer solar system can refuel.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: Compared to the Earth, it's much easier and cheaper to get things off the moon into orbit.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: Colonizing Mars may mean starting from the moon.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: But this isn't a true colony, not yet.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: The base will be abandoned if funding stops.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: If we want our base to grow into the third phase into a true colony, it must become self-sufficient, supporting itself via exports to Earth.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: Now, private contractors arrive, looking to get rich off lunar resources and support services.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: If it's cheaper to produce rocket fuel in space, what else can they get rich on?

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: They could extract precious metals, abundant in impact craters and other raw materials from the lunar red lift.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: One promising possibility is the mining of Helium 3, an isotope that could one day be used in nuclear fusion reactors, something that Chinese lunar exploration program is currently looking into.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: Future colonists may export Helium 3 back to Earth, providing us with cheap and clean fusion energy.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: Astroids could be pulled into the moon's orbit and mined.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: With commercial exports to Earth, the colony is fully in its third phase, self-sufficient and economically productive.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: Our base will begin using lunar material in its construction projects if it's to continue growing.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: Fortunately, lunar soil has all the necessary ingredients to make concrete.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: Robotic mining rigs can sift the lunar dust for organic molecules and could be used to build huge structures way too massive to be brought from Earth.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: While advances in 3D printing will make it possible to produce almost everything else the crews need.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: It's hard to say when exactly the colony becomes self-sustaining.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: Growth is gradual, experiments are replaced by industry and the population steadily reaches the hundreds encompassing more than just scientists.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: Engineers, pilots and contractors representing countries and corporations will be present.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: Two of these people will make a breakthrough, not scientific, but social.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: They will have the first extraterrestrial child.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: Throughout history, the birth of the first child was celebrated as a moment where the seed of a colony finally and irreversibly took root.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: Here, it means that the moon is not just a place for scientists and engineers to work, it's a place for people to live, to raise a family.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: Once this transition happens, the colony grows rapidly, building more habitats and schools and farms and all the things needed to support the growing population.

Title: How We Could Build a Moon Base TODAY – Space Colonization 1
Sentence: As our colony grows, all kinds of new technologies will be invented to sustain it.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: If you saw a wormhole in reality, it would appear round, spherical, a bit like a black hole.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: Light from the other side passes through and gives you a window to a far away place.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: Once crossed, the other side comes fully interview with your old home now receding into that shimmering spherical window.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: But our wormholes real, or are they just magic disguised as physics and maths?

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: If they are real, how do they work and where can we find them?

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: For most of human history, we thought space was pretty simple, a big flat stage where the events of the universe unfold.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: Even if you take down the set of planets and stars, they're still something left.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: That empty stage is space and it exists, unchanging and eternal.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: Einstein's theory of relativity changed that.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: It says that space and time make up that stage together, and they aren't the same everywhere.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: The things on the stage can affect the stage itself stretching and warping it.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: If the old stage was like unmoving hardwood, Einstein's stage is more like a waterbed.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: This kind of elastic space can be bent and maybe even torn and patched together, which could make wormholes possible.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: Let's see what that would look like in 2D.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: Our universe is like a big flat sheet.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: Bent in just the right way, wormholes could connect to very very distant spots with a short bridge that you could cross almost instantaneously.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: In abling you to travel the universe even faster than the speed of light.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: So where can we find a wormhole?

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: Presently, only on paper.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: General relativity says they might be possible, but that doesn't mean they have to exist.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: General relativity is a mathematical theory.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: It's a set of equations that have many possible answers, but not all maths describes reality.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: But they are theoretically possible and there are different kinds.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: The first kind of wormholes to be theorized were Einstein Rosen ridges.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: They describe every black hole as a sort of portal to an infinite parallel universe.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: Let's try to picture them in 2D again.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: M.D.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: space time is flat, but curved by objects on it.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: If we compress that object, space time gets more curved around it.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: Eventually, space time becomes so walked that it has no choice but to collapse into a black hole.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: A one-way barrier forms the event horizon, which anything can enter, but nothing can escape.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: Trapped forever at the singularity at its core.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: But maybe there is no singularity here.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: One possibility is that the other side of the event horizon looks a bit like how a universe again, but mirrored upside down, where time runs backwards.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: In our universe, things fall into the black hole.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: In the parallel universe, with backwards time, the mirrored black hole is spewing things out a bit like a big bag.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: This is called a white hole.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: Unfortunately, Einstein Rosenbridge's can't actually be crossed.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: It takes an infinite amount of time to cross over to the opposite universe, and they crimp shards in the middle.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: If you go into a black hole, you won't become the stuff coming out of the white hole.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: You'll only become dead.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: So, to travel the cosmos in the blink of an eye, humans need a different kind of wormhole, a traversable wormhole.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: If string theory, or one of its variations, is the correct description of our universe, then we could be lucky, and our universe might even have a tangled web of countless wormholes already.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: Shortly after the Big Bang, quantum fluctuations in the universe at the smaller scales, far, far smaller than an atom may have created many many traversable wormholes.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: Threaded through them are strings called cosmic strings.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: In the first billionth of a trillionth of a second after the Big Bang, the ends of these tiny, tiny wormholes were pulled light-years apart, scattering them through the universe.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: If wormholes were made in the early universe, whether with cosmic strings or some other way, they could be all over, just waiting to be discovered.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: One might even be closer than we realize.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: From the outside, black holes and wormholes can look very similar, leading some physicists to suggest the supermassive black holes in the centre of galaxies are actually wormholes.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: It will be very hard to go all the way to the centre of the Milky Way to find out though, but that's okay.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: There might be an equally extremely hard way to get our hands on a wormhole, we could try to make one.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: To be traversable and useful, there are a few properties we want a wormhole to have.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: First, it must obviously connect two distant parts of space time, like your bedroom and the bathroom, or earth and Jupiter.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: Second, it should not contain any event horizons which would block two-way travel.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: Third, it should be sufficiently sized so that the gravitational forces don't kill human travellers.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: The biggest problem we have to solve is keeping our wormholes open.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: No matter how we make wormholes, gravity tries to close them.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: Gravity wants to pinch it close and cut the bridge, leaving only black holes at the ends.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: Whether it's a traversable wormhole with both ends and ours, or a wormhole to another universe, it will try to close unless we have something proper in open.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: For very old string theory wormholes, that's the cosmic strings job.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: Four man-made wormholes, we need a new ingredient.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: Exotic matter.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: This isn't anything like we find on earth, or even antimatter.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: It's something totally new and different and exciting, with crazy properties like nothing that's ever been seen before.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: Exotic matter is stuff that has negative mass.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: Positive mass like people and planets and everything else in the universe is attractive because of gravity.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: But negative mass would be repulsive.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: It would push you away.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: This makes a kind of antigravity that props open our wormholes.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: And exotic matter must exert enormous pressure to push space-time open, greater even than the pressure at the centers of neutron stars.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: With exotic matter, we could weave space-time however we see fit.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: We may even have a candidate for this exotic matter, the vacuumer space itself.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: Quantum fluctuations in empty space are constantly creating pairs of particles and antiparticles, only for them to be annihilated and instant later.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: The vacuum of space is boiling with them and we can already manipulate them to produce an effect similar to the negative mass we're looking for.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: We could use this to stabilize our wormholes.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: Once we're keeping it open, the ends would start together, so we'd have to move them around to interesting places.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: We could start by wiring the solar system, leaving one end of each wormhole in orbit around the earth.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: We could fling others into deep space.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: The earth could be a wormhole hub for a vast interstellar human civilization, spread over light-years, but only a wormhole away.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: However, wormholes have a dark sight.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: Even opening a single wormhole kind of breaks the universe in the fundamental ways, potentially creating time travel paradoxes and violating the causal structure of the universe.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: Many scientists think that there's not only means they should be impossible to make, but that it's impossible for them to exist at all.

Title: Wormholes Explained – Breaking Spacetime
Sentence: So for now, we only know that wormholes exist in our hearts and on paper in the form of equations.

Sentence: We know you want to know more about universe stuff, so we're trying something new.

Title: What If You Detonated a Nuclear Bomb In The Marianas Trench? (Science not Fantasy)
Sentence: What would happen if we designated humanities most powerful nuclear weapon at the deepest point of the ocean?

Title: What If You Detonated a Nuclear Bomb In The Marianas Trench? (Science not Fantasy)
Sentence: For sure, tsunamis hundreds of meters high would destroy coastal cities, earthquakes would level countries new volcanoes would bring us nuclear winter.

Title: What If You Detonated a Nuclear Bomb In The Marianas Trench? (Science not Fantasy)
Sentence: Currently, Earth's deepest known point is inside the Mariana trench.

Title: What If You Detonated a Nuclear Bomb In The Marianas Trench? (Science not Fantasy)
Sentence: The Mariana trench is a very deep valley right at the edge of two tectonic plates that looks like an upside-down mounted.

Title: What If You Detonated a Nuclear Bomb In The Marianas Trench? (Science not Fantasy)
Sentence: It reaches a depth of about 11 km, almost three times deeper than the dark grave of the Titanic.

Title: What If You Detonated a Nuclear Bomb In The Marianas Trench? (Science not Fantasy)
Sentence: It's one of the last places on Earth for humans to explore.

Title: What If You Detonated a Nuclear Bomb In The Marianas Trench? (Science not Fantasy)
Sentence: Pitch black and under a thousand atmospheres of pressure, it's a relatively pristine environment thanks to the absence of humans.

Sentence: A great place for our nuclear test.

Title: What If You Detonated a Nuclear Bomb In The Marianas Trench? (Science not Fantasy)
Sentence: We'll use the most powerful nuclear bomb humans have ever exploded, the RDS-220 hydrogen bomb or Tsabamba.

Title: What If You Detonated a Nuclear Bomb In The Marianas Trench? (Science not Fantasy)

Title: What If You Detonated a Nuclear Bomb In The Marianas Trench? (Science not Fantasy)
Sentence: Its shockwave was strong enough to destroy everything in a thousand square kilometers, its fireball hot enough to burn the rubble.

Title: What If You Detonated a Nuclear Bomb In The Marianas Trench? (Science not Fantasy)
Sentence: Bombs like this release such an enormous amount of energy at once that they could boil away an entire lake.

Title: What If You Detonated a Nuclear Bomb In The Marianas Trench? (Science not Fantasy)
Sentence: And if we set off a nuclear bomb in the Mariana trench, that's exactly what happens.

Title: What If You Detonated a Nuclear Bomb In The Marianas Trench? (Science not Fantasy)
Sentence: Let's pour the trigger.

Title: What If You Detonated a Nuclear Bomb In The Marianas Trench? (Science not Fantasy)
Sentence: In the first few microseconds, the nuclear fuel undergoes its chain reaction and explodes with the power of 50 megatons of TNT.

Title: What If You Detonated a Nuclear Bomb In The Marianas Trench? (Science not Fantasy)
Sentence: A blinding flash of light illuminates the darkness of the trench for the first time in history.

Title: What If You Detonated a Nuclear Bomb In The Marianas Trench? (Science not Fantasy)
Sentence: The heat of the explosion produces a cavity, a flaming bubble of water vapor, radioactive nuclei and the remains of very unlucky fish.

Title: What If You Detonated a Nuclear Bomb In The Marianas Trench? (Science not Fantasy)
Sentence: The bubble grows quickly as it vaporizes the water around it.

Title: What If You Detonated a Nuclear Bomb In The Marianas Trench? (Science not Fantasy)

Sentence: And then almost as fast as it emerges, it stops.

Sentence: But the pressure at the bottom of the Mariana trench is enormous, with 11 km of water overhead, being in the Mariana trench is like being crushed by a hydraulic press from every direction.

Sentence: Here a second after detonation, our bubble is about a kilometer across, when oddly enough it starts to shrink.

Title: What If You Detonated a Nuclear Bomb In The Marianas Trench? (Science not Fantasy)
Sentence: The bubble overextends itself, losing pressure as it expands until the water turns it back, decompressing it.

Title: What If You Detonated a Nuclear Bomb In The Marianas Trench? (Science not Fantasy)
Sentence: The tug of war between the fiery death bubble and water goes back and forth a few times, the bubble shrinking and growing until eventually the bubble loses for good.

Title: What If You Detonated a Nuclear Bomb In The Marianas Trench? (Science not Fantasy)
Sentence: The pressure around it is too great and turbulent water begins to chop it up.

Title: What If You Detonated a Nuclear Bomb In The Marianas Trench? (Science not Fantasy)
