Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: Imagine if you could gather the energy from every star within 100 million light years, from thousands of galaxies, each with billions of stars.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: Imagine you could take this kind of power and use it to fire the biggest superweapon in the universe.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: Imagine the damage you could do.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: It turns out, you don't need to imagine it, these exist and they're called Gamma Raybursts.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: But what are these cosmic snipers?

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: And what happens if one takes a shot at Earth?

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: To understand Gamma Raybursts, we first have to understand Gamma Ray's.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: Gamma Ray's are electromagnetic radiation, waves which carry energy just like visible light.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: Visible light is a tiny part of the electromagnetic spectrum, it's the part your eyes can see.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: At low energies, there are radio waves, microwaves and infrared, and at higher energies, ultraviolet, x-rays and gamma rays.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: Gamma rays are incredibly powerful.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: A single gamma ray photon is more energetic than a million visible photons combined.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: Their high energy makes Gamma rays a form of ionizing radiation, meaning they are energetic enough to break apart atomic bonds.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: This makes them dangerous to you and me.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: Ironizing radiation disrupts the delicate biochemical machinery that keeps us alive like a 9mm bullet through a clock.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: Fortunately, on Earth, the Oso layer blocks Gamma rays filtering them out before they can harm us.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: But if the atmosphere blocks Gamma rays from space, how were gamma ray bursts or G-R-Bs from space ever discovered?

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: During the Cold War, the USA sent up Spice at Light, which could detect Gamma rays from Soviet nuclear tests and space.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: They didn't see any bombs, but they did observe faint bursts coming from space, lasting only a few seconds.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: To date, this may be the only major scientific discovery made by Spice satellites that we know about anyway.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: Astronomers use telescopes that see different kinds of light to make their discoveries, and these Spice satellites gave them a new pair of eyes.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: They were a mystery for 30 years, but eventually, we discovered the source of a G-R-B, a galaxy 6 billion light years away.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: If a G-R-B can be seen from such a distance, then it must be incredibly energetic, releasing more energy in a second than the Sun will in its entire 10 billion year lifetime, making G-R-Bs the brightest events in the universe.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: So where do they come from?

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: G-R-Bs accompany some of the most violent, cataclysmic deaths in the universe and the birth of black holes.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: There are two types of gamma ray bursts, short and long, and each has their own source.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: Long G-R-Bs last about a minute, and scientists think they are produced by Supernova, when the core of a massive star collapses to become a black hole.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: Short G-R-Bs lasts a second, and I'll produce two neutron stars in a binary merge.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: Over millions of years, they're all bit decayed by a meeting gravitational waves.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: Once they're close enough to touch, they crash and splash into each other, forming a black hole.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: Both Supernova and neutron star merges make the same thing.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: Black holes surrounded by a magnetized disk of gas left over from their parent stars.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: In these environments, the rotation winds up the magnetic field, which funnels hot jets of particles travelling at maybe the speed of light.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: The gas in this funnel creates two tight jets of high energy gamma rays, like a celestial laser gun, so unlike other cosmic explosions, which spread out and fade, G-R-Bs stay focused and can be seen from much further.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: Any more detail would require too much mathematics for a YouTube video.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: The universe is full of these cosmic snipers, firing blindly and randomly into the dark, and they're hitting us all the time.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: On average, we detect one per day, fortunately, most are harmless.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: All the bursts we have detected so far originated outside the Milky Way too far away to hurt us.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: But a nearby G-R-B could be disastrous if one goes off within a few light years of us, it would totally cook the surface of the Earth, or at least the half that's facing it.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: But even a more distant G-R-B could still end life on Earth.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: And it wouldn't need to score a headshot to get us.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: If originating from a few thousand light years away, it would be a hundred light years wide by the time it reaches us, Washing over the solar system like a tidal wave.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: Again, the ozone layer protects us, but it's better equipped to handle the trickle of ultraviolet from the sun.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: A gamma ray burst would overwhelm it, leaving us exposed to deadly solar radiation.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: Ozone takes years to replenish itself by natural processes, which is more than enough time for the sun to burn the Earth's sterile, or at least to kill most complex life.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: In fact, this may have already happened.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: A GR-B has been suggested as one possible cause of the order-vision extinction 450 million years ago, that are dedicated almost 85% of all marine species, although it's pretty much impossible to prove.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: Gamma ray bursts could even be one reason we don't see life anywhere else in the universe.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: They might be wiping clean, huge chunks of it on a regular basis.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: It's been suggested that because of GR-B's only 10% of all galaxies might be hospitable to life similar to us.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: So, are they going to kill us?

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: Probably not.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: In a galaxy like ours, there may only be one GR-B per millennia, and to harm us, they must be close and directed at us.

Title: Death From Space — Gamma-Ray Bursts Explained
Sentence: But since Gamma rays travel at the speed of light, we won't know when it's headed our way into the terrarys, so there could already be a GR-B on its way to kill us all, and we won't know it until it hits us, and we're dead.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: The world we live in feels normal.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Ordinary.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: It feels like this is just how humans exist and always exist it.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: But, it's not.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Never before have we humans lived in a world as sophisticated and engineered to our needs as today.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Giving us the luxury to forget about ourselves and not worry about survival.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Food, shelter, security, all of this is more or less taken for granted.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: But, we're a special few.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: From more than 99.99% of human history, life was completely different.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: And there's no such thing as just one human history.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Our story begins 6 million years ago when the tribe of Hominini split and our relationship with the apes ended.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: 2.8 million years ago the genus of Homo, the first humans emerged.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: We like to think of ourselves as the only humans, but this is far from the truth.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: When we, Homo sapiens sapiens came into existence 200,000 years ago, there were at least six other human species around.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Cousins of comparable intelligence and ability, which must have been incredibly scary, kind of like living with aliens.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Some of them were very successful.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Some were erectus, for example, survived for 2 million years, 10 times longer than modern humans have existed.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: The last of the other humans disappeared around 10,000 years ago.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: We don't know what caused them to die out.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Modern humans have at least a few percent of nyanthal and other human DNA, so there was some mixing, but certainly not enough to be a merger between species.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: So we don't know if our cousins went away because they lost the battle over resources, but because of a series of minor genocides, either way, only we remain.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Back to the beginnings of humanity.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Two point eight million years ago, early humans used tools, but did not make a lot of progress for nearly 2 million years.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Until they learned to control fire.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Fire meant cooking, which made food more nutritious, which contributed to the development of our brain.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: It also produced light and warmth, which made days longer and winter's less gruesome.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: On top of that, it not only scared predators away, it could also be used for hunting.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: A torched wood or grassland provided small animals, nuts and tubers, that were pre-roasted.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: From 300,000 years ago, most of the different human species lived in small hunter-gatherer societies.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: They had fire, wooden stone tools, planned for the future, buried their dead, and had cultures of their own.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: But most importantly, they spoke to each other, probably in a kind of proto-language less complex than ours.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: If we had a time machine, how far would we be able to go back, steal a few babies, and raise them today without anyone noticing that they're a bit different.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: There is much debate.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: An atomically modern humans emerged 200,000 years ago, but probably 70,000 years as far as we could travel back, and still snatch a behaviourally modern human.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Before that, the babies would probably lack a few crucial gene mutations necessary to build a brain with modern language and abstract thinking abilities.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: At some point around 50,000 years ago, there was an explosion in innovation.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Tools and weapons became more sophisticated, and culture became more complex, because at this point, humans had a multipurpose brain and a more advanced language to communicate information with each other effectively and down to the last detail.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: This allowed much closer cooperation and is what really makes us different from any other creature on Earth.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Not our comparatively weak bodies and inferior senses, but the ability to cooperate flexibly in large groups, unlike, for example, rigid beehives, or intimate, but tiny wolf packs.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: As our brain evolved, we became able to do something life had been unable to do after this point.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: One, expand knowledge quickly.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Two, preserve the knowledge gained over generations.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Three, build on past knowledge to gain even deeper insights.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: This seems laughed, but until then, information had to be passed on from generation to generation, mostly through genetics, which is not efficient.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Still, for the next 40,000 years, human life remained more or less the same.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: There was little to build upon.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Our ancestors were only one animal among many.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Building a skyscraper without knowing what a house is, is hard.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: But one is easy to be arrogant in our attitude to our ancestors.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: This would be a current.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Humans, 50,000 years ago, were survival specialists.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: They had a detailed mental map of their territory.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Their senses were fine tuned to the environment.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: They knew and memorized a great amount of information about plants and animals.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: They could make complicated tools that required years of careful training and very fine motor skills.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Their bodies compare to our athletes today, just because of their daily routines, and they lived a rich social life within their tribe.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Survival required so many skills that the average brain volume of early modern humans might even have been bigger than it is today.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: As a group, we know more today, but as individuals, our ancestors were superior to us.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Then around 12,000 years ago, in multiple locations, humans developed agriculture.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Everything changed very quickly.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Before, survival as a hunter and farer-age required superb physical and mental abilities in all fields from everybody.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: With the rise of the agricultural age, individuals could increasingly rely on the skills of others for survival.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: This meant that some of them could specialize.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Maybe they worked on better tools.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: But they took time to breathe more resistance crops or better livestock, maybe they started inventing things.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: As farming got more and more efficient, what we call civilization began.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Agriculture gave us a reliable and predictable food source, which allowed humans to hoard food on a large scale for the first time, which is much easier to do with grains than meat.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: A food stock required protection, which led to communities living together in tighter spaces.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: First early defense structures were built, the need for organization grew.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: The more organized we got, the faster things became efficient.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Villages became cities, cities became kingdoms, kingdoms, became empires.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Connections between humans exploded, which led to opportunities to exchange knowledge.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Progress became exponential.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: About 500 years ago, the scientific revolution began.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: The mathematics physics, astronomy, biology and chemistry transformed everything we thought we knew.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: The industrial revolution followed soon after, laying the foundation for the modern world.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: As our overall efficiency grew exponentially, more people could spend their lifetime contributing to the progress of humanity.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Revolutions kept happening.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: The invention of the computer, its evolution into a medium we all use on a daily basis and the rise of the internet, shaped our world.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: It's hard to grasp how fast all of that happened.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: It's been about 125,000 generations since the emergence of the first human species.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: About 7,500 generations since the physiologically modern human sort the light of day.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: 500 generations ago, what we call civilization began.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: 20 generations ago, we learned how to do science.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: And the internet became available to most people only one generation ago.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Today, we live in the most prosperous age humanity has ever experienced.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: We have transformed this planet, from the composition of its atmosphere to large scale changes in its landscape and also in terms of the other animals in existence.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: We light up the night with artificial stars and put people in a metal box in the sky.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Some have even walked on our moon.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: We've put robots on our planet.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: We've looked deep into the past of the universe with mechanical eyes.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Our knowledge and our way of acquiring and storing more of it has exploded.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: The average high school student today knows more about the universe than a scholar of few centuries ago.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Humans dominate this planet, even if our rule is very fragile.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: We are still not that different from our ancestors 70,000 years ago, but your lifestyle has existed for less than 0.001% of human history.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: From here on, there's no saying what the future holds for us.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: We're building a skyscraper, but we're not sure if it's standing on a solid foundation, or if we're building it on quicksand.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Let's leave it with that for now.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: The next time you miss your train, your burger is not hot enough, or someone cuts in line, remember how special this made up human world is.

Title: What Happened Before History? Human Origins
Sentence: Maybe it's not worth being upset about all those little things.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Are you your body?

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Well, kind of right, but is there a line where this stalks being true?

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: How much of yourself can you remove before you stop being you?

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: And does the question even make sense?

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Your physical existence is cells.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Traillions of them, at least ten times more than there are stars in the Milky Way.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: A cell is a living being, a machine made of up to 50,000 different proteins.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: It has no consciousness, no will, no purpose, it just is.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: But it is still an individual.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Together, your cells form huge structures for jobs like preparing food, gathering resources, transporting stuff around, scanning the environment, and so on.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: If you extract cells from your body and put them in the right environment, they will continue to stay alive for a while.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: So, your cells can exist without you.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: But you can't exist without them.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: If we take all the cells away, there is no you anymore.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Is there a line where a pile of your cells stops being you?

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: For example, if you donate an organ, billions of your cells will continue to live on inside someone else.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Does this mean that a part of you became a part of another person?

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Or is this other body keeping a part of you alive?

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Or let us imagine an experiment, you and a random person from the street exchange cells.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: One at a time, your body gets one of their cells, their body gets one of your cells, and at which point would they become you?

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Would they ever, or is this just a very slow and gross way to teleport you?

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Let's make this more complicated.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: The image of ourselves as a static thing is untenable.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Almost all of your cells have to die during your lifetime.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: 250 million have died since the beginning of this video alone.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Between one and three million per second.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: In a seven year period, most of your cells are replaced at least once.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Every time your cells set up changes, you are slightly different than before.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: So a part of you is dying constantly.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: If you are lucky enough to become old, you would have cycle through roughly a million, billion cells.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: So what you consider yourself is ready just a snapshot.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: But sometimes cells are broken and don't want to die.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Questioning the very nature of the unity of our bodies.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: We call them cancer.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: They cancel the biological social contract and become basically immortal.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Cancer is not an outside invader.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: It's a part of you that puts its own survival over yours.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: But you could also argue that a cancer cell becomes another entity inside us, another being that just wants to thrive and survive.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Can we blame it for that?

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: A chilling cell story is that of Henrietta Lacks.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: A young cancer patient who died in 1951.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Usually cells only survived for a few days in the lab, making research very hard.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Henrietta's cancer cells were immortal.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Over the decade, they were multiplied over and over again and used for countless research projects, saving countless lives.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Henrietta's cells are still alive and overall have been grown to at least 20 tons of biomass.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: So there are living parts around the world from someone who has been considered dead for decades.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: How much of Henrietta is in these cells?

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: What makes one of your cells you anyway?

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Maybe the information contained in it.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Your DNA.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Until recently, it was believed that all the cells in your body had basically the same genetic code.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: But it turns out this is wrong.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Your genome is mobile, changing over time through mutations and environmental influences.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: This is especially the case in your brain.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: According to recent discoveries, a single neuron in an adult brain has more than 1,000 mutations in its genetic code than a present in the cells surrounding it.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: But how much you is your DNA, really?

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: About 8% of the human genome is made up of viruses that once infected our ancestors and merge with us.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Mytercondria, how are plants of the cell once were bacteria that merge with the ancestors of yourselves?

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: They still have their own DNA.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: An average cell has hundreds of them, hundreds of little things that are not really human, but they still kind of are.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: It is confusing.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Let's backtrack a bit.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: We know that you're made up of trillions of little things made from more little things that are constantly changing.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Together, all those little things are not static, but dynamic.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Their composition and condition is changing constantly.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: So, we might just be a self-sustaining pattern without clear borders that gained self-awareness at some point, and now has the ability to think about itself through time and space, but ready only exists in this exact very moment.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Where did this pattern start?

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: With your conception, when the first human arose, when life first began conquering our small planet, or when the elements that make up your body were forged in a star, our human reigns evolved to deal with absolute.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: The fuzzy borders that make up reality are hard to grasp.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Maybe ideas like beginning and end, life and death, you and me are really not absolute, but ideas belonging to a fluent pattern, a pattern that is lost in this strange and beautiful universe.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: The problem of who we are isn't just a question of ourselves, but it's also a question of our minds.

Title: What Are You?
Sentence: Just as our cells can be divided and separated from us, so can our very brains be divided and separated from us.

Title: How Far Can We Go? Limits of Humanity (Old Version – Watch the New One)

Title: How Far Can We Go? Limits of Humanity (Old Version – Watch the New One)

Title: How Far Can We Go? Limits of Humanity (Old Version – Watch the New One)

Title: How Far Can We Go? Limits of Humanity (Old Version – Watch the New One)

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: Terrorism is very scary, especially when it happens close to home and not in some faraway place.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: Nobody likes to be afraid, and we were eager to make the fear go away, so we demanded more security.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: In the last decade, it's become increasingly normal for civil liberties to be eroded and for government agencies to spy on citizens, to collect and store their personal information.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: Regardless of whether you're a fan of right or left wing policies, this affects every one of us.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: So we have to take a look at the data and ask ourselves honestly, has all of this actually made us safer?

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: In the aftermath of 911, the US government concluded that the law had not kept pace with technology.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: It created the terrorist surveillance program initially to intercept communications linked to our kider.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: Officials were confident that if the program had been in place before 911, the hijackers could have been stopped.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: But soon the new powers were also used to prove guilt by association.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: The FBI used immigration records to identify Arab and Muslim foreign nationals in the US.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: On this basis, 80,000 individuals were required to register, another 8,000 were called in for FBI interviews, and more than 5,000 locked up in preventive detention.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: Not one terrorist was found in what's been called the most aggressive national campaign of ethnic profiling since World War II.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: How commonplace it since become for government agencies to collect and store the personal data of citizens was made plain by the leak of the Snowden documents in 2013.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: They showed how the NSA can demand information about users from firms like Microsoft or Google in addition to their daily collection of data from civilian internet traffic, such as email content and contact lists.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: So instead of focusing on criminals, governments are increasingly turning their attention to everyone.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: But if you're looking for a needle in a haystack, adding more hate to the stack isn't going to make it any easier to find the needle.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: On the contrary, every recent success announced by the NSA has come from classic target surveillance.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: Despite high hopes, the NSA surveillance program has not stopped any major terror attack.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: For instance, one of the Boston Marathon bombers was already a target of the FBI.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: So what we need is not even more random data, but better ways to understand and use the information we have.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: The spy agencies are also pushing too cripple encryption.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: In early 2016, the FBI asked Apple to produce a backdoor program to disable the encryption of a terrorist's iPhone.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: Apple publicly declined not only because this tool could be used to permanently weaken the privacy of law-abiding citizens worldwide, but referring to open the floodgates for governments requesting access to a technology used by billions of people.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: A fair shared by security experts and cryptographers.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: A few weeks later, the FBI revealed that they had hacked the phone themselves, basically admitting that they lied to the public about the need for a bad door.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: Which questions how trustworthy spy agencies are in the debate about privacy and security?

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: Especially considering that the NSA, for example, already has the capability to turn on your iPhone microphone or activate your laptop camera without un noticing.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: Concerned about this are often met with the argument, if you have nothing to hide, you have nothing to fear.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: But this reasoning only creates a climate of oppression.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: Wanting to keep certain parts of your life private doesn't mean you're doing anything wrong.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: Right now, we live in a democracy, but imagine the damage the role person could do with all our data and such easy access to our devices.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: Anti-terrorism laws allow the authorities to investigate and punish long terrorism-related crimes more aggressively.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: If you give law enforcement powerful tools, they will use them.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: That's why democratic oversight is so important, even if those tools and laws aren't used against you today, they might be tomorrow.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: For example, following the November 2015 Paris attacks, France expanded its already extensive anti-terrorism laws by giving law enforcement greater powers to conduct house rates and place people under house arrest.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: Within weeks, evidence emerged that these powers were being used for unintended purposes, such as caution climate change protests.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: The governments of Spain, Hungary, and Poland have introduced more restrictive laws on the freedom of assembly and speech.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: Freedom of expression and the press in Turkey has been seriously undermined in the last few years, with people sentenced to prison for criticizing the government.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: None of this is effectively helping us fight terrorism.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: The motivation behind this might be good, even noble, but if we let our elected governments limit our personal freedom, the terrorists are winning.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: What's worse, if we're not careful, we might slowly move towards a surveillance state.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: The data is pretty clear.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: The erosion of rights along with mass surveillance hasn't led to significant successes so far, but it has changed the nature of our society.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: Terrorism is a complicated problem.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: Without simple solutions.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: No security apparatus can prevent a few guys from building a bomb in their basement.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: We should keep the principle of proportionality in mind.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: Creating mass decrees to enter millions of phones is not the same as searching a single house.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: In most countries, the law already permits a wide range of actions, including targeted surveillance.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: To take full advantage of this existing potential, we need better international cooperation and more effective security and foreign policies.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: Better application of our present laws instead of new and strict to ones that undermine our freedom.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance
Sentence: Let us not out of fear destroy what we are most proud of, democracy and our fundamental rights and liberties.

Title: Safe and Sorry – Terrorism & Mass Surveillance

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: It's hard to get to space.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: As much as we all wish there were an easy and affordable way to see our planet floating in the dark, right now the only way is to become an astronaut or a billionaire.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: But there is a concept that might make it possible while serving as the starting point for the exploration of the universe, the Space Elevator.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: How exactly does it work?

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: To understand how a Space Elevator will get us into space, we must first understand what an orbit is.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: Being in orbit basically means falling towards something that moving fast enough to miss.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: If you throw a ball on earth, it makes an arc through the air and then hits the ground.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: In space, gravity makes you move much the same way, but if you move sideways fast enough, the curvature of the earth makes the ground fall away beneath you as fast as gravity pulls you towards it.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: So to enter Earth's orbit, rockets have to go up and sideways fast.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: By contrast, a space elevator taps into energy from the Earth's rotation to get the cargo going fast.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: Imagine a child spinning a toy on a rope with an ant on the child's hand.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: As the ant climbs out along the rope, it starts to move faster and faster as it ascends.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: Compared to rockets with cargo launched on an elevator, you only need to provide the energy to go up.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: Fast sideways movement comes free with the Earth's rotation.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: But a space elevator would without a doubt be the single largest and most expensive structure ever built by humans.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: So is it worth it?

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: It all comes down to costs.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: rockets burn a huge amount of rocket fuel just to get a small amount of cargo into space.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: At current prices, it costs about $20,000 to but one kilogram of payload into space.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: That's $1.3 million for the average human, $40 million for your car.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: Billions for an international space station.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: This immense cost is one of the major limitations of human space flights, even with advancing technology this cost isn't likely to be comparable with the price of an airline ticket anytime soon.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: A space elevator would solve this problem.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: After construction, a space elevator is protected to reduce the cost 100fold to $200 per kilogram.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: If an inexpensive space elevator costs $20 billion, then we'll recuper losses after launching only 1,000 tons.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: Close to the weight of two international space stations.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: So what would a space elevator look like in real life?

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: A space elevator has four major components.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: The Tether, Anker, Counterweight and Climber.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: The elevator part of the space elevator is the Tether and the Climber.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: It extends from the surface of the Earth to space.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: The Climber is like a conventional elevator carriage, a chamber that works its way up and down the Tether.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: At the base would be an anchor, pitting the Tether to the Earth along with a port for climbers.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: At the top is the counterweight which holds up the Tether.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: The Tether is held tight like a rope and supported from above by the tension from the counterweight.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: Located higher than 36,000 kilometers above the Earth's surface.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: At the counterweight could be a space station, a launching point for all missions from the space port elevator.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: But can we actually build one?

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: It's hard to say.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: The biggest challenge is the Tether.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: It needs to be light, affordable, and more stable than any material we can produce right now.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: There are promising materials like graphene and diamond nanothreads, but even they may not be strong enough.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: And, aside from being incredibly strong, the Tether would also have to withstand atmospheric corrosion, radiation, and micrometriot and debris impacts.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: Additionally, it takes several days to climb the elevator.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: How do we power the climber?

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: It requires a lot of energy to go up.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: Do we need a nuclear reactor on our elevator carriage?

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: Or do we beam it power from the ground with a super powered laser?

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: And where do we get the raw materials for a 36,000-colour-to-long Tether?

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: Do we make it on Earth and launch it into space?

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: Or do we make it in space and lure it down to the Earth?

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: Could asteroid mining with the answer?

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: Put simply, there are still some major technological hurdles to overcome.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: And a space elevator is not without risk.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: Should the Tether break, it would collapse in spectacular style.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: If it breaks near the anchor, the force exerted by the counterweight will cause the entire elevator to rise up, ascending into space.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: Should it break near the counterweight, the Tether will fall, racking around the world and whipping the end off?

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: The resulting debris in orbit could pose serious problems to future spaceflight.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: If we build a space elevator on Earth, we have to do it right the first time.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: For these reasons, some experts have proposed first building a space elevator on the moon.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: The moon's gravity is much weaker than the Earth, so a flimsyar but exist in material like Kevlar could serve as a Tether.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: Even with all these challenges, the payoff of having a working space elevator would be immense.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: It might be the first step to truly becoming a space-faring civilization.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: Maybe we will never build a space elevator, but in trying to do so, we might learn an awful lot.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: And when it comes to the exploration of the universe, there can't be too many dreams of a glorious future.

Title: Space Elevator – Science Fiction or the Future of Mankind?
Sentence: That's it.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: What would you say if we told you that humanity is currently making a collaborative effort to engineer the perfect Superbug?

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: A bug that could kill hundreds of millions of people?

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: Well, it is, happening right now.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: We are in the process of creating a Superbacterium.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: The Bacteria are among the oldest living things on this planet.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: The smallest thing we still consider life, they are masters of survival and can be found everywhere.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: Most bacteria are harmless to us.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: Your body hosts trillions of them and they help you to survive.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: But others can invade your body, spread quickly and kill you.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: Millions of people used to die as a result of bacterial infections until we developed a superweapon antibiotics.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: Together with vaccinations antibiotics revolutionized medicine and saved millions of lives.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: Antibiotics kill the vast majority of susceptible bacteria fairly quickly, leaving only a small group of survivors that are immune system then deals with easily.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: How do antibiotics do this?

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: Imagine a bacterium as a very complex machine with thousands of complex processes going on that keep it alive and active.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: Antibiotics disrupt this complex machinery, for example, by interfering with its metabolism, slowing down their growth significantly so they are less of a threat.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: Other antibiotics attack DNA and prevent it from being replicated, which stops bacteria from multiplying, ultimately killing them.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: Or by simply ripping the outer layer of the bacteria to shreds so that their insights spill out and they die quickly.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: All of this, without bothering body cells.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: But now evolution is making things more complicated.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: My pure random chance, a small minority of the bacteria invading your body, might have evolved away to protect themselves.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: For example, by intercepting the antibiotics and changing the molecule so it becomes harmless.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: Or by investing energy in pumps that eject the antibiotics before they can do damage.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: A few immune bacteria are not that big a deal because the immune system can take care of them.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: But if they escape, they might spread their immunity.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: How can bacteria spread immunity?

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: First of all, bacteria have two kinds of DNA.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: The chromosome and small free floating parts called plasmids.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: They can hug each other and exchange those plasmids to exchange useful abilities.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: This way, immunity can be spread quickly through a population.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: Or an a process called transformation, bacteria can harvest dead bacteria and collect DNA pieces.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: This even works between different bacteria species and can lead to super bugs.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: Bacteria that are immune to multiple antibiotics.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: A variety of super bugs already exist in the world, especially hospitals, other perfect breeding grounds for them.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: Humans have short memories.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: The horrors of the pre-antibartegera have been forgotten.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: Today, we treat this powerful medicine as a commodity instead of as the game-changer-cheath-winter science that it is.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: This has led to a strange disconnect.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: Hundreds of millions of people still don't have access to antibiotics in developing countries.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: While in other parts of the world antibiotics are prescribed too freely and taken without care.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: Antibartegs should be a last resort drug, not something you take because your cold is a 9.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: Another serious problem is antibiotic use in meat production.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: At any particular point in time, humanity holds between 20 and 30 billion animals as livestock.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: To make meat cheaper, many animals are held in horrible conditions in very tight spaces and in unhygienic conditions.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: The perfect breeding ground for a disease.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: So many animals are given antibiotics to kill as many bacteria as possible and prevent them from getting sick, because the cheeseburger has to cost a dollar.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: Unsurprisingly, as a result of this system, we have created more and more bacteria that are resistant to antibiotics.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: To counteract this, we use different antibiotics and we have another secret weapon.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: There are specific antibiotics that are used to wipe out bacteria that have developed resistance.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: There are strict rules for using these to avoid the creation of a superbacterium.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: Or, so we thought.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: In late 2015, scary news arrived from China.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: Resistance against Calistin, a last-ditch antibiotic had been discovered.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: Calistin is an old drug and was ready-used because it can damage the liver.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: So there was little resistance against it, which made it a great antibiotic of last resort for certain complex infections that occur in hospitals, to fight bacteria that have become immune to a whole bunch of other drugs.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: Bacteria resistance to colistin is very very bad news.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: It might destroy a last line of defense and lead to a whole lot of dead people.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: How could this happen?

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: Millions of animals in Chinese pick farms have been given colistin for years.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: Resistance bacteria developed spreading first from animal to animal and then to humans without being noticed.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: On an average day, there are over 100,000 flights on Earth, kind of connecting every human on the planet.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: By creating the modern world, we have also built the infrastructure for a dangerous pandemic.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: Still, we don't need to panic just yet.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: Bacteria evolved humans to research.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: New antibiotics are developed as old ones become obsolete.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: Technology is advancing every day.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: The problem is real and serious, but the fight is far from over.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: If humanity plays its cards right, Superbucks might turn out to be not very super after all.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained
Sentence: If you want to support us to make more videos, you can buy a cut-cuzard poster or mug or donate on Patreon.

Title: The Antibiotic Apocalypse Explained

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: Over 40 years ago, US President Richard Nixon declared drug abuse public enemy number 1, starting an unprecedented global campaign for war on drugs.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: Today, the numbers are in.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: The war on drugs is a huge failure with devastating unintended consequences.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: It led to mass incarceration in the US, two corruption, political destabilization and violence in Latin America, Asia and Africa, two systemic human rights abuses across the world.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: It negatively affected the lives of millions of people.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: All of this, while we waste billions of dollars every year, only to create and fuel powerful drug cartels, while the goal of the war on drugs seems less achievable than ever, a world without drugs.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: How could this happen?

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: The core strategy of the war on drugs is no drugs, no problems.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: So almost all of the efforts in the last few decades have been focused on eradicating the supply of drugs and incarcerating drug traffickers.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: But this ignores the most fundamental of market forces, supply and demand.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: If you reduce the supply of anything without reducing the demand first, it's price goes up.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: This might lower sales for many products, but not for drugs.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: The drugs market is not price-sensitive.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: Drugs will be consumed no matter what they cost.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: So the effect is to encourage production of more drugs and recruitment of more traffickers, which increases availability.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: This is also known as the balloon effect.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: Even if drug production or a major supply route is destroyed, the supply for the end user is not reduced.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: A perfect example of this is Crystal Meth.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: The US government tries to stop its production by strictly regulating the sale of chemicals used to manufacture the drug.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: This forced big-med producers out of business, but the unintended consequences were that thousands of small-scale operations started all over the country.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: Mostly in small towns and rural communities using chemicals that weren't regulated.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: In response to this, some US states wanted to reduce the supply of homegrown meth by regulating even more chemicals, which reduced small-scale meth production drastically.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: But the supply of meth still stayed the same.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: Mexican drug cartels immediately took over and opened big production operations.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: Their meth was even better than it was before, and they had loads of experience in smuggling.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: So all these efforts made meth production more professional.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: The drug more potent, while supply wasn't reduced at all.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: You can't win this war on the supply site.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: Not only are drugs widely available, demand unbroken, and some drugs pureer than in the past.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: With a budget of around $30 billion, the US drug enforcement agency has an efficiency rate of less than 1%.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: When it comes to stopping the flow of drugs into the US and inside the US.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: For many miners around the world, it's as easy to get a legal drugs as alcohol.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: But it doesn't stop here.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: Prohibition may prevent a certain amount of people from taking drugs, but in the process, it causes huge damage to society as a whole.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: Many of the problems we associate with drug use are actually caused by the war against them.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: For example, prohibition makes drugs stronger.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: The more potent drugs you can store in as little space as possible, the more profit you'll make.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: It was the same during alcohol prohibition, which led to an increased consumption of strong liquor over beer.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: The prohibition of drugs also led to more violence and murders around the world.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: Gangs and cartels have no access to the legal system to settle disputes, so they use violence.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: This led to an ever-increasing spiral of brutality.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: According to some estimates, the homicide rate in the US is 25-75% higher because of the war on drugs.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: And in Mexico, a country on the front line, an estimated 164,000 have been murdered between 2007 and 2014.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: More people than in the war zones of Afghanistan and Iraq in the same period combined.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: But whether war on drugs might do the most damage to society is the incarceration of non-violent drug offenders.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: For example, the United States, one of the driving forces of the war on drugs, has five percent of the world's total population, but 25 percent of the world's prison population, largely due to the harsh punishments and mandatory minimums.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: Minorities suffer because of this especially.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: African Americans make up 40 percent of all US prison inmates, and while white kids are more likely to abuse drugs, black kids aren't ten times more likely to get arrested for drug offenses.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: Okay, but is there actually something different we could do?

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: Is there a way out of this mess?

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: In the 1980s, Switzerland experienced a public health crisis related to heroin use.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: HIV rates skyrocketed and street crime became a problem.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: Swiss authorities tried a new strategy, harm reduction.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: They opened free heroin maintenance centers where addicts would be treated and stabilized.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: Here, people would be given free heroin of high quality, they would get clean needles, and have access to safe injection rooms, showers, beds and medical supervision.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: Social workers help them find housing and deal with other problems in their lives.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: The results were a sharp drop in drug related crime, and two thirds of the people in the centers got regular jobs, because now they could focus on getting better instead of financing their addiction.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: Today, over 70 percent of all heroin addicts in Switzerland received treatment.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: HIV infections have dropped drastically.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: Deaths from heroin overdoses have dropped by 50 percent.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: And drug related street sex work and crime has been reduced enormously.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: So there are methods that are not only way cheaper, but also actually work instead of creating more problems.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: Drug prohibition led to a system that bulldozes human rights, costs, vast sums of money, and creates a lot of human misery.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: All in pursuit of an unobtainable goal.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: After 40 years of fighting, it's time to finally end the war on drugs and move on to something better.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: This video was supported by the Open Society Foundation's and by viewer donations on Patreon.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: If you want to learn more about how you can influence drug policy, check out the Stop the Harm campaign.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure
Sentence: We finally have the merchandise.

Title: Why The War on Drugs Is a Huge Failure

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: One day the last star will die and the universe will turn dark forever.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: It will probably be a red dwarf, a tiny kind of star that's also one of our best bets to find alien life and might be the last home of humanity before the universe becomes uninhabitable.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: Also what do we know about them and why are they our last hope?

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: At least 70% of stars in the universe are red dwarfs.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: They are the tonyestars out there, with only about 7% to 50% of the mass of our sun, not that much bigger than our planet Jupiter, which is still huge though.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: They are also very dim.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: It's impossible to see them with the naked eye.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: You've never seen one in the night sky.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: Even with all our technology, we can only clearly observe red dwarfs in our neighborhood.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: Approximately 20 of the 30 stars close to Earth are red dwarfs.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: Like old stars, red dwarfs fuse hydrogen into helium.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: But while more massive stars accumulate all the fuse helium in their cause, red dwarfs stay convective, meaning that the helium and hydrogen constantly mix, so they use up their fuel incredibly slowly before their extinguished.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: Red dwarfs burn so slowly that that average lifespan is between one and 10 trillion years.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: By comparison, the sun will survive for another 5 billion years.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: Because the universe is only 13.75 billion years old, not a single red dwarf has reached later development stages.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: Every single one of the trillions that exist is still a baby.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: Speaking of babies, the smallest star in the entire universe is also a red dwarf, because small red dwarfs are right on the verge of being a star at all, just a tiny bit less hydrogen and they are mere brown dwarfs, failed stars that cannot sustain a fusion reaction for long.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: So what about aliens or a new home for humanity?

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: Since our sun will die one day, we'll eventually need to look for a new home, and where there are habitable planets, they're might or so, be aliens.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: The Kepler Space Observatory found that at least half of all red dwarfs host rock planet between half and four times the mass of our earth.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: Many of them are in the habitable zone, the area around a star where water can be liquid.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: But since red dwarfs burn at relatively cold temperatures, a planet would need to be really close to be hospitable, probably as close as mercury to our sun or even closer.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: Which brings with it all kinds of problems.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: For example, a planet this close to a star would probably be tightly locked, meaning the same side would always face it.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: This side would be incredibly hot while the shadows side would be frozen, which makes it hard for life to develop.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: Although a planet with a bigger version might be able to distribute the star's energy and create some kind of stability.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: All the gravitational forces of the red dwarf could squeeze the planet and heat it up so much, but it might lose all its water over time.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: These planets could end up like Venus, a hot, burning hell.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: Another problem is that many red dwarfs vary in their energy output.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: They can be covered in star spots that condemn their emitted light by up to 40% for months, which would cause oceans on planets to freeze over.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: At other times they can emit powerful solar flares, sudden outbursts of energy, incredibly powerful.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: These red dwarfs could double their brightness in minutes, which could strip away sizable portions of a planet's atmosphere and burn it, rendering its sterile.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: On the other hand, their extremely long lifespan is a big plus.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: A red dwarf with just moderate levels of activity could be an amazing place for a planet that hosts life.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: Earth has existed for about 4 billion years, and we have about a billion years left before the sun becomes so hot that complex life on Earth will become impossible.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: We will either die out or leave Earth and look for a new home.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: We could build a civilization for potentially trillions of years around a red dwarf with the right conditions.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: About 5% of the red dwarfs in the Milky Way may host habitable, roughly Earth-sized planet.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: That would be more than 4 billion in total.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: But life may not even need a planet like Earth.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: Candidates for life around a red dwarf may be the moons of gas giants, also called Super Earth's, really massive rocky planets.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: All old, there are an estimated 60 billion potentially habitable planets around red dwarfs, and that's in the Milky Way alone.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: So red dwarfs might become really important for our survival in the future.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: But everything has to die at some point, even red dwarfs.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: When in trillions of years the life of the last red dwarf in the universe is about to end, it will not be a very spectacular event.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: As its 100-runs out its shrinks becoming a blue dwarf burning out completely.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: After its fuel is spent, it's transformed into a white dwarf, an object about a small Earth packed very densely and made of degenerate gases, mostly of helium-formucly.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: Having no more source of energy, it will cool extremely slowly over trillions of years until it becomes its final form, a cold, black dwarf.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: White and black dwarfs are so fascinating that they deserve their own video.

Title: The Last Star in the Universe – Red Dwarfs Explained
Sentence: Anyway, it's going to be a long time before the last stars in the universe vanish, it's kind of uplifting to know that if humanity succeeds in venturing into space, we have plenty of time before the universe turns out the lights.
