Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: Three reasons why we should stop using nuclear energy.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: One, nuclear weapons proliferation.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: Nuclear technology made a violent entrance onto the world stage.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: Just one year after the world's first ever nuclear test explosion in 1944, two large cities were destroyed by just two single bombs.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: After that, react to technology slowly evolved as a means of generating electricity, but it's always been intimately connected with nuclear weapons technology.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: It's nearly impossible to develop nuclear weapons without access to react to technology.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: In fact, the nuclear non-proliferation treaty serves the purpose of spreading nuclear react to technology without spreading nuclear weapons with limited success.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: In 40 years, five countries have developed their own weapons with the help of react to technology.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: The fact of the matter is that it can be very hard to distinguish a covert nuclear weapons program from the peaceful use of nuclear energy.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: In the 1970s, the big nuclear powers were happily selling peaceful technology to smaller countries which then developed weapons of their own.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: The road to deadly nuclear weapons is always paved with peaceful reactors.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: Two, nuclear waste and pollution.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: Spent nuclear fuel is not only radioactive, but also contains extremely poisonous chemical elements and like plutonium.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: It loses its harmfulness only slowly over several tens of thousands of years.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: And there is also a process called reprocessing, which means the extraction of plutonium from spent nuclear fuel.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: It can be used for two purposes to build nuclear weapons or to use it as new fuel.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: But hardly any of it is used as fuel because we don't have the right kind of reactors for that.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: A milligram will kill you a few kilograms make an atomic bomb and even an inconspicuous country like Germany literally has tons of the stuff just lying around because reprocessing sounded like a good idea decades ago.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: And where will all the waste go?

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: After dumping it into the ocean was forbidden, we've tried to bury it, but we can't find a place where it will definitely stay secure for tens of thousands of years.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: Over 30 countries operate nearly 400 reactors, managing several hundred thousand of tons of nuclear waste and only one is currently serious about opening a permanent civilian waste storage, tiny Finland.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: Three, accidents and disasters.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: Over 60 years of nuclear power usage, there have been seven major accidents in reactors or facilities dealing with nuclear waste.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: Three of those were mostly contained, but four of them released significant amounts of radioactive into the environment.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: In 1957, 1987 and 2011, large areas of land in Russia, Ukraine and Japan were rendered unfit for human habitation for decades to come.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: The number of deaths is highly disputed, but probably lies in the thousands.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: These disasters happened with nuclear reactors of very different types in very different countries and several decades apart.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: Looking at the numbers, we may as well ask ourselves, are 10% of the world's energy supply worth a devastating disaster every 30 years.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: We're 30% be worth another Fukushima or Chernobyl somewhere on Earth every 10 years.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: What area would have to be contaminated so we say no more?

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: Where is the lime?

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: So, should we use nuclear energy?

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: The risks may outweigh the benefits and maybe we should stop looking into this direction and drop this technology for good.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Terrible! 2/3
Sentence: If you want to hear the other side of the environment or a short introduction to nuclear energy, click here.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: Three reasons why we should continue using nuclear energy.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: One, nuclear energy saves lives.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: In 2013, a study conducted by NASA found that nuclear energy has prevented around 1.8 million deaths.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: Even if you include the death tolls from Chernobyl and Fukushima, nuclear energy ranks last in death per energy units produced.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: While nuclear waste is really toxic, it's usually stored somewhere.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: While the toxic byproducts of fossil fuels are pumped into the air we breathe every day.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: So, just by reducing the amount of fossil fuels burned, countless cases of cancer or lung disease and accidents in coal mines have been avoided.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: If we can choose between lots of dangerous stuff being put into a deep hole, and lots and lots and lots of dangerous stuff being pumped into the atmosphere, the former seems more logical.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: Nuclear energy feels way more dangerous though.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: Single catastrophic events burn into our memory while coal and oil kill simultaneously.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: It's like the death rate of flying versus driving.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: Even in the best case scenario, it would take at least 40 years to switch to 100% renewable energy.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: So, for as long as we continue using fossil fuels, nuclear energy will save way more lives than it destroys.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: Two, nuclear energy reduces CO2 emissions.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: Nuclear energy is arguably way less harmful to the environment in terms of climate change than fossil fuels, our main source energy.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: Since 1976, about 64 gigatons of greenhouse gas emissions have not been pumped out, thanks to nuclear energy.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: And by the mid-21st century, that could amount to an additional 82, 240 gigatons.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: Humanity's energy consumption is rising steadily.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: According to US government projections, China alone will add the equivalent of a new 600-megawatt coal plant every 10 days for the next 10 years.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: China already burns 4 billion tons of coal each year.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: Coal is cheap, relatively abundant, and easy to get to, so it's not likely that humanity will stop using its soon.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: Nuclear energy might be the only way of dampening the effects of climate change and preventing a catastrophic man-made global warming.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: Compared to the other things we do, nuclear energy is relatively clean.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: So, even if it is a good idea to quit nuclear energy long-term, it might be a good solution for the next 100 years or so, compared to the alternatives.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: Three, new technologies.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: Maybe technology will solve the problem of nuclear waste and dangerous power plants.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: The nuclear reactors we've used so far are mostly outdated technology, because nuclear innovation stopped in the 1970s.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: There are models like the thorium reactor that could solve the problem altogether.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: Thorium is abundant, really hard to turn into nuclear weapons, and up to 2 orders of magnitude less wasteful than current nuclear reactors.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: The waste material might also be only dangerous for a few hundred years, in contrast to a couple of thousand years.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: One ton of thorium is estimated to provide the same amount of energy as 200 tons of uranium or 3.5 million tons of coal.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: So while we cannot know for sure if alternative nuclear technology will keep its promises, shouldn't we at least do more research before we forego an opportunity to solve lots of humanities current problems?

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: It might not be an easy challenge, but that hasn't stopped us before.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: So, should we use nuclear energy?

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: There are risks involved in any great human endeavor, and we have to make an informed decision rather than rely on gut-feaning.

Title: 3 Reasons Why Nuclear Energy Is Awesome! 3/3
Sentence: If you want to hear the other side of the argument or a short introduction to nuclear energy, click here.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: Have you ever been in an argument about nuclear power?

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: We have, and we found it frustrating and confusing, so let's try and get to grips with this topic.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: It all started in the 1940s, after the shock and horror of the war in the use of the atomic bomb, nuclear energy promised to be a peaceful spinoff of the new technology, helping the world get back on its feet.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: The one's imagination was running wild, would electricity become free, could nuclear power help settle the Antarctic, would there be nuclear power cars, planes or houses?

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: It seemed that this was just a few years of hard work away.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: One thing was certain, the future was atomic.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: Just a few years later, there was a sort of atomic H-H-H-O-Va, as it turned out, nuclear power was very complicated and very expensive.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: Learning physics into engineering was easier, but hard in real life.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: Also, private companies thought that nuclear power was much too risky as an investment, most of them would much rather stick with gas, coal and oil.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: But there were many people who didn't just want to abandon the promise of the atomic H, an exciting new technology.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: The prospect of enormously cheap electricity, the prospect of being independent of oil and gas imports, and in some cases, a secret desire to possess atomic weapons provided a strong motivation to keep going.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: Nuclear powers, finest hour, finally came in the early 1970s when war in the Middle East caused oil prices to skyrocket worldwide.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: Now, commercial interest and investment picked up at a dazzling base.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: More than half of all the nuclear reactors in the world were built between 1970 and 1985, but which type of reactor to build, given how many different types there were to choose from.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: It was a surprising underdog candidate one the day, the light water reactor.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: It wasn't very innovative, and it wasn't too popular with scientists, but it had some decisive advantages.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: It was there, it worked, and it wasn't terribly expensive.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: So what does a light water reactor do?

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: Well, the basic principle is shockingly simple, it heats up water using an artificial chain reaction.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: Nuclear fission releases several million times more energy than any chemical reaction could.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: The reality heavy elements on the brink of stability, like uranium 235, get bombards with neutrons.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: The neutron is absorbed, but the result is unstable.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: Most of the time, it immediately spits into fast moving lighter elements, some additional free neutrons, and energy in the form of radiation.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: The radiation heats the surrounding water, while the neutrons repeat the process with other atoms releasing more neutrons and radiation in a closely controlled chain reaction.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: Very different from the first destructive runaway reaction in an atomic bomb.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: In our light water reactor, a moderator is needed to control the neutron's energy.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: Simple, ordinary water does the job, which is very practical, since water is used to drive the turbines anyway.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: The light water reactor became prevalent because it's simple and cheap.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: However, it's neither the safest, most efficient, nor technically elegant nuclear reactor.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: The renewed nuclear hype lasted barely a decade though.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: In 1979, the 3 Marlilin nuclear plant in Pennsylvania, barely escaped a catastrophe when it's core melted.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: In 1986, the Chernobyl catastrophe directly threatened Central Europe with a radioactive cloud, and in 2011, the drawn-out Fukushima disaster sparked new discussions and concerns.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: While in the 1980s, 218 new nuclear power reactors went live, their number and nucleus global share of electricity production has stagnated since the end of the 80s.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: So what's the situation today?

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: Today, nuclear energy meets around 10% of the world's energy demand.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: There are about 439 nuclear reactors in 31 countries, about 17 new reactors are under construction in 2015, most of them in countries which are growing quickly.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: All in all, 116 new reactors are planned worldwide.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: First new reactors were built more than 25 years ago with pretty old technology.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: More than 80% are various types of light water reactor.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: Today, many countries are faced with a choice, the expensive replacement of the aging reactors possibly with more efficient but less tested models or a move away from nuclear power towards newer or older technology with different cost and environmental impacts.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: So should we use nuclear energy?

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: The pro and contra arguments will be presented here next week.

Title: Nuclear Energy Explained: How does it work? 1/3
Sentence: Subscribe and then you won't miss it.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: The International Banking System is an enigma.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: There are more than 30,000 different banks worldwide, and they hold unbelievable amounts of assets.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: The top 10 banks alone account for roughly 25 trillion US dollars.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: Today, banking can seem very complex, but originally, the idea was to make life simpler.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: The International Banking System is a very important thing.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: 11th century Italy was the centre of European trading.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: Merchants from all over the continent met to trade their goods, but there was one problem.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: Too many currencies in circulation.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: In Pisa, merchants had to deal with seven different types of coins and had to exchange their money constantly.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: This exchange business, which common need to place outdoors on benches, is where we get the word bank from, from the word bankol, Italian for Bench.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: The dangers of travelling, counterfeit money, and the difficulty of getting a loan got people thinking.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: It was time for a new business model.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: Home brokers started to give credit to businessman, while Genoese merchants developed cashless payments.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: Networks of banks spread all over Europe, handing out credit even to the church or European kings.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: What about today?

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: In a nutshell, banks are in the risk management business.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: This is a simplified version of the way it works.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: People keep their money in banks and receive a small amount of interest.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: The bank takes this money and lends it out at much higher interest rates.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: It's a calculated risk because some of the vendors will default on their credit.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: This process is essential for our economic system, because it provides resources for people to buy things like houses or for industry to expand their businesses and grow.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: So banks take funds that are unused by savers and turn them into funds society can use to do stuff.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: Other sources of income for banks include accepting saving deposits, the credit card business, buying and selling currencies, custodian business, and cash management services.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: The main problem with banks nowadays is that a lot of them have abandoned their traditional role as providers of long-term financial products in favour of short-term gains that carry much higher risks.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: During the financial boom, most major banks adopted financial constructs that were barely comprehensible and did their own trading in a bit to make fast money and earn their executives and traders millions in bonuses.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: This was nothing short of gambling and damaged whole economies and societies.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: Like back in 2008, when banks like Lehman Brothers gave credit to basically anyone who wanted to buy a house and thereby put the bank in an extremely dangerous risk position.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: This led to the collapse of the housing market in the US and parts of Europe causing stock prices to plummet, which eventually led to a global banking crisis and one of the largest financial crises in history.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: Hundreds of billions of dollars just evaporated.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: Millions of people lost their jobs and lots of money.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: Most of the world's major banks had to pay billions in fines and bankers became some of the least trusted professionals.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: The US government and the European Union had to put together huge bailout packages to purchase bad assets and stop the banks from going bankrupt.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: New regulations were put into force to govern the banking business, compulsory bank emergency funds were enforced to absorb shocks in the event of another financial crisis.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: But other pieces of tough new legislation were successfully blocked by the banking lobby.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: Today other models of providing financing are gaining ground fast.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: Like new investment banks that charge a yearly fee and do not get commissions on sales, thus providing the motivation to act in the best interests of their clients.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: All credit unions caught the initiative that were established in the 19th century to circumvent credit sharks.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: In a nutshell, they provide the same financial services as banks, but focused on shared value rather than profit maximization.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: The self-proclaimed gold is to help members create opportunities like starting small businesses, expanding farms or building family homes while investing back into communities.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: They are controlled by their members who also elect the board of directors democratically.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: Worldwide, credit union systems vary significantly, ranging from a handful of members to organisations worth several billion US dollars and hundreds of thousands of members.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: The focus on benefits for their members impacts the risk credit unions are willing to take, which explains why credit unions, although also hurting, survive the last financial crisis way better than traditional banks.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: Not to forget the explosion of crowdfunding in recent years.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: Aside from making awesome video games possible, platforms arose that enable people to get loans from large groups of small investors, circumventing the bank as a middleman.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: But it also works for industry.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: Lots of new technology companies started out on Kickstarter or Indiegogo.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: The funding individual gets the satisfaction of being part of a bigger thing and can invest in ideas they believe in.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: While spreading the risks so widely, that if the project fails, the damage is limited.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: And last but not least, micro credits.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: Lots of very small loans, mostly hand out in developing countries that help people escape poverty.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: People who were previously unable to get access to the money they needed to start a business because they weren't deemed worth the time.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: Nowadays, the granting of micro credits has evolved into a multi-billion dollar business.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: So banking might not be up your street, but the bank's role of providing funds to people and businesses is crucial for our society and has to be done.

Title: Banking Explained – Money and Credit
Sentence: Who will do it and how it will be done in the future is up for us to decide, though.

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: Recently, there's been a lot of talk about measles.

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: What does measles actually do?

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: And should you vaccinate against this?

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: Or is this just hysteria?

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: Measles is a virus.

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: A hull of proteins are an A plus some more proteins for reproduction.

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: It cannot reproduce by itself.

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: It needs a host cell to do so.

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: To understand measles, we have to understand the immune system.

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: You might already have seen the visual system we developed to help here.

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: Now, let's focus on the parts of the immune system relevant to measles.

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: The measles virus enters humans through the nose, mouth, or eyes.

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: The measles infection starts in the lungs.

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: Measles is especially good at infecting the body's first line of defense, macrophages, powerful guard cells that protect the lungs from intruders.

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: They enter a cell and take it over.

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: The virus reprograms the cell and transforms it into a dangerous virus production center.

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: Once the cell is filled with viruses, they leave the crippled cell and begin the cycle over again.

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: But the immune system has powerful weapons against virus infections, natural killer cells.

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: These cells basically patrol the body and check other cells for infections.

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: If they find an infected cell, they order it to commit suicide.

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: This is a effective that for the first 10 days or so, you will not even notice the jaw infected with measles.

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: And now, the reason why measles is so powerful.

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: After a period of fighting and dying, macrophages alert the brain of the immune system, the dentritic cells.

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: The job of the dentritic cells is to collect samples of intruders, travel to the lymph nodes, and then activate the heavy weapons that eradicate the infection very fast in a team effort.

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: But the measles virus uses a dreadful tactic.

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: It infects the dentritic cells and uses them as a Trojan horse to enter deeper into the body.

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: The infected cells travel to the next lymph nodes to alert other immune cells.

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: Once it arrives, the measles virus spreads around the virgin T and B cells and infects them.

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: It attacks the very system that evolved to fight it.

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: Now, things happen very fast.

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?
Sentence: The lymph system spreads the virus everywhere and it enters the bloodstream, infecting cells while traveling.

Title: Measles Explained — Vaccinate or Not?

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: Life is fundamentally different from dead stuff, or is it?

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: Physicists are eventually spreading a defined life this way.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: Living things avoid decay into disorder and equilibrium.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: What does this mean?

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: Let's pretend that your download folder is the universe.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: It started oddly and got more and more chaotic over time.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: By investing energy, you can create order and clean it up.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: This is what living things do.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: But what is life?

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: Every living thing on this planet is made of cells.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: Basically, a cell is a protein based robot too small to feel or experience anything.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: It has the properties we just assigned to life.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: It has a wall that separates it from the surroundings creating order.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: It regulates itself and maintains a constant state.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: It eats stuff to stay alive, it grows and develops, it reacts to the environment, and it's subject to evolution, and it makes more of itself.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: But of all the stuff that makes up a cell, no part is alive.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: Stuff reacts chemically with other stuff forming reactions that start other reactions, which start other reactions.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: In a single cell, every second, several million chemical reactions take place, forming a complex orchestra.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: A cell can build several thousand types of protein, some very simple, some complex micro machines.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: Imagine driving a car at 100km an hour while constantly rebuilding every single part of it, with stuff you collect from the street.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: That is what cells do.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: But no part of the cell is alive, everything is dead matter, moved by the laws of the universe.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: So is life the aggregate of all these reaction processes that are taking place?

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: Eventually, every living thing will die.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: The goal of the whole process is to prevent this by producing new entities.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: And by this, we mean DNA.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: Life is in a way just a lot of stuff that carries genetic information around.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: Every living thing is subject to evolution, and the DNA that develops the best, living thing around it will stay in the game.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: So is DNA life then?

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: If you take DNA out of its hull, it certainly is a very complex molecule, but it can't do anything by itself.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: This is where viruses make everything more complicated.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: They are basically strings of RNA or DNA in a small hull, and need cells to do something.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: We're not sure if they count as living or dead, and still there are 225 million cubic meters of viruses on Earth.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: They don't seem to care what we think of them.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: There are even viruses that invade dead cells and reanimate them, so they can be a host for them, which blows the line even more.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: Or mitochondria.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: They are the power plants of most complex cells, and were previously free living bacteria that entered a partnership with bigger cells.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: They still have their own DNA and can multiply on their own, but they are not alive anymore.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: They are dead.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: So they traded their own life for the survival of their DNA, which means living things can evolve into dead things as long as it's beneficial to their genetic code.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: So maybe life is information that manages to ensure it's continued existence.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: But what about AI?

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: Artificial intelligence.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: By our most common definitions, we are very close to creating artificial life in computers.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: It's just a question of time before the technology we build gets there.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: And this is not science fiction either.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: There are a lot of smart people actively working on this.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: You could already argue the computer viruses are alive.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: Hmm.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: Okay, so what is life then?

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: Things, processes, DNA, information?

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: This got confusing very fast.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: One thing is for sure, the idea that life is fundamentally different from non-living things because they contain some non-physical element or are governed by different principles than in animal objects turns out to be wrong.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: Before Charles Darwin, humans draw a line between themselves and the rest of living things.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: There was something magical about us that made us special.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: Once we had to accept we are like every living being, a product of evolution, we drew a different line.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: But the more we learn about what computers can do and how life works, the closer we get to creating the first machine that fits out description of life, the more our image of ourselves is in danger again.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: And this will happen sooner or later.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: And here's another question for you.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: If everything in the universe is made of the same stuff, does this mean everything in the universe is dead, or that everything in the universe is alive?

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: That it's just a question of complexity.

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: Does this mean we can never die because we were never alive in the first place?

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: Is life and death an irrelevant question and we haven't noticed it yet?

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?
Sentence: Is it possible we are much more part of the universe around us than we thought?

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?

Title: What Is Life? Is Death Real?

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: What makes Ebola so dangerous?

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: How can a virus overwhelm the very complex defence system of the body so quickly and so effectively?

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: Let's take a look at what Ebola does.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: Ebola is a virus, a virus is a very small thing.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: A bit of RNA or DNA and a few proteins in a hole.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: It has no ability to do anything by itself whatsoever and can only survive and proliferate by infecting cells.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: To avoid this, we have the immune system.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: The immune system is super complex, so we develop to visual system that makes it easy to understand.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: So it looks like this.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: Let's concentrate on the part that's critical to understanding Ebola and ignore the rest.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: So, usually, then-dritic cells would activate an army of anti-virus cells, support cells and antibody factors that would, together with the God cells, wipe out the infection in a matter of days.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: But when Ebola strikes, it directly attacks the immune system.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: Some of the cells it takes over are the dendritic cells, the brains of the immune system.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: The Ebola virus enters a dendritic cell by binding onto receptors for cell transport.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: Once it's inside, it dissolves its outer hull and releases its genetic material, nuclear proteins and enzymes.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: In a nutshell, it takes over the cell, disables the cells' protective mechanisms and reprograms it.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: The cell now becomes a virus production machine and uses its resources to build Ebola viruses.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: Once the cell is saturated, it dissolves the cell membrane and millions of viruses are released into the tissue.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: The virus not only prevents the dendritic cell from activating the specialized anti-virus forces, it manipulates it into sending signal proteins that trick the specialized cells into ending their own lives prematurely.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: So the immune system is seriously disrupted and unable to react, while the virus rapidly multiplies.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: We're talking billions.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: There are cells that should deal with infected cells, the natural killer cells, but they also get infected and just die before they can prevent the disease from spreading.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: At the same time, Ebola infects the guard cells of the body, macrophages and monocytes.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: Not only managing two circumvent their defenses, it also manipulates them to signal to the cells that make up the blood vessels, telling them to release fluids into the body.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: Usually, this makes sense, but in this case, it just causes mayhem.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: All over the body, neutrophils are activated, are working by the virus and the macrophages signals.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: They're not very effective against viruses, and should not be involved in this fight and begin to do lots of stuff they shouldn't do.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: The neutrophils signal the blood vessels to release more fluid, causing internal bleeding.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: Another area of the body Ebola attacks is the liver.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: The virus finds it very easy to enter the liver, and it quickly starts killing loads of liver cells, and causing organ failure and more internal bleeding.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: And all of those things are going on at the same time.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: As the virus spreads, it's like nukes exploding everywhere.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: One incident of this in one region would be probably enough, but now it's starting to happen everywhere at once.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: All the mechanisms the immune system has evolved to handle infections work against you, and the virus continues to spread and spread, and finally begins to infect more and more body cells, where the body desperately struggles to stay alive.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: In a desperate last effort to turn the tide, the immune system launches a cytokine storm.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: A cytokine storm is an SOS signal, that causes the immune system to launch all of its weapons, all at once, in a desperate, comacasia attack.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: This hurts the virus, but leaves behind tons of collateral damage, especially in the blood vessels.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: Paradoxically, the healthy of the immune system, the more damage it can do to itself.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: More and more fluid leaves the bloodstream.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: Blood pours out of every opening of the body.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: You become seriously dehydrated.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: There's just not enough blood left to supply the organs with oxygen and cells begin to die.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: If you reach this point, the chance of you dying is very high.

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival
Sentence: Currently, six out of ten infected die from Ebola.

Sentence: Wow.

Sentence: So it's time to panic, right?

Title: The Ebola Virus Explained — How Your Body Fights For Survival

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: Violence and war.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: The insane brutality of ISIS continues.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: The Russians are invading Ukraine and the Palestinians and Israelis continue to slug it out.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: Does that make you feel gloomy?

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: Well, don't.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: Because if you look at the numbers, more actually seems to be going out of fashion.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: While the global population is as an all-time high, it seems that we live in the most peaceful period in human history.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: How is this possible?

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: As of September 2014, there were four conflicts going on in the world that had caused at least 10,000 people to die since January 2013.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: Nine conflicts that killed more than 1,000 people and 13 that killed more than 100 since January 2013.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: Not really peaceful, but consider this.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: Of all the conflicts going on, none is an active war between countries.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: They are either civil wars or local conflicts.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: Although civil wars are terrible and cause huge suffering, their impact is usually way smaller than a war between nations or empires.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: When two nations engage in war, they can mobilize much bigger forces, have access to all of the states' resources and logistics and almost to all of the population.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: So why have we transitioned from wars between nation states to civil wars?

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: A lot of it is to do with colonialism and the Cold War.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: When the Cold War ended, a major driver of armed conflict vanished too.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: But the breakup of the communist dictatorship revealed new or old tensions and brought new conflicts in the now-free state which often resulted in civil war.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: Much more importantly, in 1945, nearly all of Africa, much of Asia and parts of Latin America were under colonial rule.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: By 1990, all but a few islands were independent.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: But wait, couldn't you argue that what today's multinational corporations are doing in the third world is just as bad as colonialism?

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: Let's look at Congo.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: It was established as a colony in 1885 by the Belgian King, an area 80 times the size of Belgium.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: Violence committed against the indigenous Congolese and the ruthless system of economic exploitation had killed about half of the population by 1908.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: About 10 million Congolese were executed all staff to death.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: Millions were mutilated and traumatized.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: The economic exploitation of the Congo remained the top priority and forced labor never really ceased completely until the end of Belgian rule in 1960, which is not really that long ago.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: So no, colonialism was much worse than a Voltaic capitalism is today and it ended just two generations ago.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: Most of the conflicts that are going on right now are in areas that 60 years ago were under foreign control.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: But things are getting better.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: Until 1989, victory for one side of a civil war was common, while nowadays, victories are much rarer.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: At the same time, negotiated endings have jumped from 10% to almost 40%.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: What about the rest of the world?

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: Why have nation states stopped attacking each other?

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: There are four major reasons.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: One, democratization, the steady development from autocracy to democracy.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: Democracy is hardly ever fighting each other.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: Of all the state against state wars fought since 1900, only a minority were fought between democracies.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: Two, globalization.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: War is just not as effective at achieving economic goals as it used to be.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: Today, it's almost always cheaper to buy resources on the global market than to seize them by force.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: People from other nations are more valuable to us alive than dead, which overall is the pretty new concept.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: Three, war is so 20th century.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: Until World War I, Warfare was seen as an inevitable part of the human experience, and as a valuable tool, which you could use to achieve goals when diplomacy hit a great wall.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: Today, we have rules that declare acts of aggression illegal and stipulate that armed forces only justified in self-defense or with the authority of the UN Security Council.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: These rules are still broken, but today it's harder to do so without sparking opposition and disapproval.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: Also, we have an international court for war crimes in the Hague, and that's a very recent innovation.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: Four, borders are mostly fixed now.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: After World War II, territorial wars generally start when most countries pledge to accept international borders and respect other nations or autonomy.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: But is all of this just an anomaly or are we on the road to lasting peace?

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: Truth is, we don't know yet.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: We need a big enough sample to roll out the historical average, which is about one or two big wars per century.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: We just haven't had enough time since World War II to roll out the possibility that war is not going away.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: If we don't have one major war in the next 75 years, we can be really confident that humanity is changing.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: So, you see, war might be over.

Title: Is War Over? — A Paradox Explained
Sentence: Yes, there are nasty conflicts going on in many places, but overall, things are getting better, and we can make them even better by speaking up for peace and democracy.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: Neutron stars are one of the most extreme things in the universe.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: They're like giant atom cores, kilometres in diameter, unbelievably dense and violent.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: But how can something like this even exist?

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: The life of a star is dominated by two forces being in balance.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: It's own gravity and the radiation pressure of its fusion reaction.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: In the core of stars, hydrogen is fused into helium.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: Eventually, the hydrogen in the core is exhausted.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: If the star is massive enough, helium is now fused into carbon.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: The cause of these massive stars become layered like onions, as heavier and heavier atomic nuclei build up with the center.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: Carbon is fused into neon, which leads to oxygen, which leads to silicon.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: Eventually, the fusion reaction hits iron, which cannot fuse into another element.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: When the fusion stops, the radiation pressure drops rapidly.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: The star is no longer in balance, and if its core mass exceeds about 1.4 solar masses, a catastrophic collapse takes place.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: The outer part of the core reaches velocities of up to 70,000 kilometres a second, as it collapses towards the center of the star.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: Now, only the fundamental forces inside an atom are left to fight the gravitational collapse.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: The quantum mechanical repulsion of electrons is overcome, and electrons and protons fuse into neutrons, packed as densely as an atomic nucleus.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: The outer layers of the star are catapulted into space in a violent supernova explosion.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: So, now we have a neutron star.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: Its mass is between 1 and 3 tonnes, but compressed to an object about 25 kilometres wide.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: And 500,000 times the mass of Earth in this tiny ball that's roughly the diameter of Manhattan.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: It's so dense that one cubic centimeter of neutron star contains the same mass as an iron cube 700 metres across.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: That's roughly 1 billion tonnes, as massive as Mount Everest, in a space the size of a sugar cube.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: Neutron star gravity is pretty impressive too.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: If you were to drop an object from 1 metre over the surface, it would hit the star in 1 metre second, and accelerate up to 7.2 million kilometres per hour.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: The surface is super flat, with a regularity of 5mm maximum, with a super thin atmosphere of hot plasma.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: The surface temperature is about 1 million Kelvin, compared to 5800 Kelvin for our sun.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: Let's look inside the neutron star.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: The crust is extremely hard, and is most likely made of an iron atom nuclei lattice with a sea of electrons flowing through them.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: The closer we get to the core, the more neutrons at fewer protons we see, until there's just an incredibly dense soup of indistinguishable neutrons.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: The cores of neutron stars are very, very weird.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: We're not sure what their properties are, but our closest guess is super fluid, neutron to generate matter, or some kind of ultra dense quark matter, called quark-glue-on-plasma.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: That doesn't make any sense in the traditional way, and can only exist in such an ultra-extreme environment.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: In many ways, a neutron star is similar to a giant atom core.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: The most important difference is that atom cores are held together by strong interaction and neutron stars by gravity.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: As if all this wasn't extreme enough, let's take a look at a few other properties.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: Neutron stars spin very very fast, young ones several times per second, and if there's a poor star nearby to feed the neutron star, it can rotate up to several hundred times per second.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: Like the object PSR, J1 748 2446 AD.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: It spins at approximately 252 million kilometers per hour.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: This is so fast that the star has a rather strange shape.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: We call these objects pulsars because they emit a strong radio signal, and the magnetic field of a neutron star is roughly a trillion times stronger than the magnetic field of Earth, so strong that atoms get bent when they enter its influence.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: Okay, I think we got the void across.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: Neutron stars are some of the most extreme, but also some of the coolest objects in the universe.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: Hopefully, we'll one-based end spaceships to learn more about them and take some neat pictures.

Title: Atoms As Big As Mountains — Neutron Stars Explained
Sentence: But we shouldn't get too close.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: Planet Earth is the home of every life formed known to us in the universe.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: Its age is about a third of the age of the universe, and admitted it is a thing of beauty.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: A slightly squash sphere with a heavy metal core and a lighter surface crust wrapped in a thin sliver of sweet air to breathe.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: With vast oceans, fertile plains, magnificent mountains, fresh water rivers, streams, lakes and aquavers, orbiting a star which warms us and gives us energy.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: But how did our home come into existence and what's it made of?

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: 4.6 billion years ago Earth was created from the remnants of dead stars that collected in a giant dirty gas cloud.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: The gas cloud became dense or in its centre and formed a de-cretion disk.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: Small particles started clumping together and building lighter and larger objects until they formed the objects we call planets today.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: This process took 10 to 20 million years and is still not very well understood.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: At about this time when the solar system was young and chaotic, a giant object about as big as Mars collided with our home.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: The impact was violent and if the object had been more massive, it might have destroyed Earth.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: Material from Earth was smashed out into orbit and formed the moon, which is the biggest satellite in relation to its planet in the solar system.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: At this time, Earth was a hot hell, constantly being hit by asteroids with seas of lava and a toxic atmosphere.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: But something was about to change drastically.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: Earth cooled down.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: Water from the inside of the Earth wandered to the surface and rained down on Earth only to vaporise again and become cloud.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: Millions of asteroids brought more and more water to our planet.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: All the water on Earth has about this volume compared to Earth.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: Today, the surface of Earth is 71% water and 29% land.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: 97.5% is saline water, while only 2.5% is fresh water.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: The fresh water is 69% ice and snow, 30% are ground waters and only about 1% they come from the remaining ground waters.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: But even this small part is mostly frozen.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: Only a tiny part of our water is actually lakes and rivers and an even tiny part is bound in living things.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: So, gradually the Earth cooled down and the surface formed a thin crust, but inside the Earth, heart rock continued to swell about, moving the crust from below and breaking it apart.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: This process is called plate tectonics and is happening right now.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: We'll make a whole video about it in the future.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: For now, let's just say that the crust of Earth consists of separate giant plates that move around, as they meet big crumble and create mighty mountains.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: Or violently plunge back down deeper into Earth, creating deep trenches.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: That's the way the highest place on Earth was formed, Mount Everest and the deepest, the Marianne of trench.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: From our perspective, Earth's mountains and trenches are mighty indeed, but when you look at the Earth in cross section, you can see how tiny they actually are.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: The part we stand on is the crust, which is about 50 kilometres thick, though it can vary between 5 and 70 kilometres.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: By the way, the deepest hole ever drilled by man is 12.262 kilometres deep.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: After the crust comes the mantle, it's a silicon rocky shell and about 2,900 kilometres thick.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: The mantle consists of the upper mantle and the lower mantle.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: The upper mantle has different regions too, its upper part, which is viscous and carries the crust, is called the lithosphere.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: After that, there comes the estenosphere, which consists of less mobile, mostly solid material.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: The lower mantle reaches deep down to the outer core of Earth.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: Earth's outer core is a liquid layer of iron and nickel, about 2,266 kilometres thick.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: Temperatures vary from 4,000 degrees Celsius to 5,700 degrees Celsius.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: And in the center is the inner core.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: It's mostly solid, the more made of an iron nickel alloy, with a radius of about 1200 kilometres.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: 70% of the size of the moon and about the temperature of the surface of the sun.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: It is slowly growing as an estimated rate of about 1mm per year.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: Now for some perspective, this small layer of crystallized milk products of former molten mantle is where we live.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: Then, there's Earth's magnetic field.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: It's an invisible phenomenon that diverts high energy particles coming from the sun and other sources, allowing for a stable environment with comparatively little radiation impact on Earth.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: But why is it there?

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: Actually, we don't really know a terrible lot about that.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: We know it has something to do with the core of the Earth.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: Inside this metal sphere, large electrical currents flow in complicated patterns.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: They cause a magnetic field that sort of stabilizes itself according to the laws of electromagnetic.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: This entire system is called the dynamo, but don't let us fall you into thinking we have it all figured out.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: Speaking of breathtaking information, what about the airy stuff that surrounds us?

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: By volume, dry air consists mostly of nitrogen, oxygen, argan, carbon, a variable amount of water vapor and small amounts of other gases.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: Humans are very dependent on the lowest layer of the atmosphere, the troposphere, where the weather is.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: It's 12 kilometers thick on average.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: Above that is the stratosphere, which is where the ozone layer protects us from the sun's most aggressive type of light.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: Above that is the mesosphere, the coolest place on Earth, with an average temperature around –85°C.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: As about 80km up, the thermosphere starts.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: The transition to space is a fluent one without clear borders, but humans decided that space starts here.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: At about 100km, Earth stops and space begins, though the atmosphere extends a bit further.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: In this region we find the island's sphere, the Aurora Borealis, and the ISS.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: And the outermost layer is the exosphere, stretching up to 10,000 km.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: It merges fluently with outer space, where there's no atmosphere at all.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: The atoms and molecules in this area are so far apart that they can travel hundreds of kilometres without colliding with each other.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: OK, humans in their present form have only been around for 200,000 years.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: That's 0.004% of Earth's history.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: Not non-really.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: And here we are now, living in a thin moist layer on a small wet rock.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: We call this rock Earth.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: It is the product of the Universe's deepest workings, the result of a constant process of creation and destruction, happening all over the Universe all the time, helped by chance, the laws of the Universe and random events.

Title: Everything You Need to Know About Planet Earth
Sentence: We are really lucky.

Sentence: They start using up the body's resources and dull their numbers about every 20 minutes.

Sentence: The immune system has to stop them as fast as possible.

Sentence: They are huge cells that guard every border region of the body.

Sentence: They swallow the intruder hole and trap it inside a membrane.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: Then the enemy gets broken down by enzymes and is killed.
