Sentence: On top of that, they cause inflammation by ordering the blood vessels to release water into the battlefield so fighting becomes easier.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: You notice this as a very mild swelling.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: When the macrophages fight for too long, they call in heavy backup by releasing messenger proteins that communicate location and urgency.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: Nutrothars leave their patrol routes in the blood and move to the battlefield.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: The neutrophars fight so furiously that they kill healthy cells in the process.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: On top of that, they generate barriers that trap and kill the bacteria.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: They are indeed so deadly that they have evolved to commit suicide after five days to prevent them from causing too much damage.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: If this is not enough to stop the invasion, the brain of the immune system kicks in.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: The dendritic cell gets active.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: It reacts to the signals of the soldiers and starts collecting samples from the enemies.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: They rip them into pieces and present the parts on their outer layer.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: Now that dendritic cell makes a crucial decision, should they call for anti-virus forces that eradicate infected body cells or an army of bacteria killers?

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: In this case, anti-bacteria forces are necessary.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: It then travels to the closest lymph node in about a day.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: The billions of helper and killer T cells are waiting to be activated.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: When T cells are born make-over through a difficult and complicated training process and only a quarter survives, the surviving cells are equipped with a specific setup.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: And the dendritic cell is on its way looking for a helper T cell with a setup that's just right.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: It's looking for a helper T cell that can bind to the parts of the intruders which the dendritic cell has presented on its membrane.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: When it finally finds one, the chain reaction takes place.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: The helper T cell is activated, equically duplicates thousands of times.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: Some become memory T cells that stay in the lymph node and will make you practically immune against this enemy.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: Some travel to the field of battle to hellbound.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: And the third group goes on to travel to the center of the lymph node to activate a very power for weapons factory.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: Like the T cells, they're born with a specific setup.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: And when a B cell and a T cell with the same setup meet, hell breaks loose.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: The B cell duplicates rapidly and starts producing millions of little weapons.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: They work so hard that they would literally die from exhaustion very fast.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: Here, helper T cells play another important role, they stimulate the hard working factories and tell them, don't die yet, we still need you.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: Keep going.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: This also ensures that the factories die if the infection is over so the body doesn't waste energy or hurt itself.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: But what is produced by the B cells?

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: You've heard of them, of course.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: The B cells are the same as the body.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: Little proteins that are engineered to bind to the surface of the specific intruder.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: There are even different kinds of antibodies that have slightly different jobs.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: The helper T cells tell the plasma cells which type is needed the most in this particular invasion.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: Millions of them flood the blood and saturate the body.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: Meanwhile, at the site of infection, the situation is getting dire.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: The intruders have multiplied a number and start hurting the body.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: They can't send a text cells fight hard but also die in the process.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: Help a T cells support them by ordering them to be more aggressive and to stay alive longer.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: But without help, they can't overwhelm the bacteria.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: But now the second line of defense arrives.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: Millions of antibodies flood the battlefield and disable lots of the intruders rendering them helpless or killing them in the process.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: They also stun the bacteria and make them an easy target.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: Their back is built to connect to killer cells so they can connect and kill the enemy more easily.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: Microphages are especially good at no-ming up the bacteria which antibodies have attached to.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: Now the balance shifts.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: In a team effort, the infection is wiped out.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: At this point, millions of body cells have already died.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: No big deal, the losses are quickly replenished.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: Most immune cells are now useless and without the constant signals they commit suicide, so is not to waste any resources.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: But some stay behind the memory cells.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: If this enemy is encountered ever again in the future, they will be ready for it and probably kill it before you even notice.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: This was a very very simplified explanation of parts of the immune system at work.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: Can you imagine how complex this system is?

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: Even at this level, when we ignore so many players and all the chemistry.

Title: The Immune System Explained I – Bacteria Infection
Sentence: Life is awfully complicated, but if we take the time to understand it, we always encounter endless wonders and great beauty.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: Are you alone in the universe?

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: Or are you connected to anything?

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: First of all, you're part of a group of mammals that's still very young, but we can make YouTube videos already and build large Hadron colitis.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: We've also split the atom and invented Pokemon.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: We stem from an ancient life form that began living about three and a half billion years ago.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: We feel like we're in control of this planet, but we aren't really.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: One little asteroid or one creative virus is already all it would take to kill us off for good.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: Humanity credits itself would be able to destroy the planet, but even with all our nuclear toys, we would probably just cause a huge mass extinction at best.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: Maybe we could kill 90% of everything living on this planet?

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: Big deal!

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: A few million years later, life would be back everywhere.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: Most microscopic life and life below the surface wouldn't even be disturbed that much probably.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: On a geological timescale, our impact on Earth is kind of laughable.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: We're actually not that powerful.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: We live on this tiny wet rock that speeds through space following a massive ball of burning plasma.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: One day, this ball of plasma will stop burning and most likely kill us in the process.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: If we survive the death of the sun and colonize the galaxy theoretically, we could survive until the last star in the universe goes out.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: After that, life becomes pretty impossible.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: Okay, so everything has an end.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: Where does this leave you, as an individual?

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: At one point in your life, for about half an hour, you were only one single cell inside your mother's womb.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: A creature just 0.1mm in diameter.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: Today, you consist of about 50 trillion cells.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: 50 trillion incredibly complex little biological machines, but a much bigger and more complex than the average bacteria.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: They operate by the laws of physics and chemistry, and use micro machines to build proteins make energy usable, devour, foods, transport resources, transmit information or reproduce.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: They communicate, duplicate, commit suicide, fight off intruders, and fulfill super-specialised duties for the greater good of keeping the energy of the universe.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: The way to good of keeping you alive, so you can have babies.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: But where is the you part in this if you're made of trillions of little things?

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: The basic information for you is stored in the DNA.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: A molecule that encodes the genetic instructions used in the development and functioning of all known living things.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: If you were to unravel it, it would be 2 metres long.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: If you combined all the little DNA strings in all your cells, you'd get a string so long that it would stretch to Pluto and back to Earth.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: That's pretty long.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: And your DNA is a direct connection to your very first ancestor.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: Take a second to think about this.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: In every cell of your body, there's a little string of stuff that's been there in various forms for 3.4 billion years.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: It evolved, it mutated, it jubligated trillions of times, but it directly connects you to the first living being on this planet.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: We could say you touched every living being that came before you with your DNA.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: But you are more than your DNA.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: Your body is made of seven octillion atoms.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: That's 7 billion billions.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: Roughly 93% of the mass of the human body is made up of just three elements, oxygen, carbon and hydrogen.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: Oxygen and hydrogen are predominantly found in water, which makes up about 60% of the body by weight.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: Carbon is maybe the most important element for life.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: It can easily bond with other atoms, which allows for the building of long, complex chains of molecules, which make up the solid part of you.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: The remaining 7% is a tour of the periodic table of elements.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: Nitrogen calcium phosphorous potassium sulfur sodium chlorine magnesium ion fluorine zinc copper iodine, seledium chromium manganese maliptonum, cobalt lithium, strong TM aluminium, silicon lead, vanadium, arsenic and bromine.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: By the way, this also means you're about 0.5% metal, no matter what your favorite music is.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: Anyway, these elements perform various functions like enabling oxygen transport, building of bones and cell structures, carrying signals, driving chemical reactions and a lot more.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: Your body is in a constant state of transition.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: Every 16 days, 75% of you has been replaced because a healthy human exchanges about 100% of their water in that time period.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: Each year, about 98% of your atoms are replaced by new ones, and every 5 years, close to all of the atoms that make up your body weren't there 5 years ago.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: So, you could call yourself a temporary collection of atoms.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: But where did these atoms come from?

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: In the beginning of the universe, there were mostly hydrogen and helium atoms.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: In enormous gas clouds formed over millennia and grew denser and denser until they collapsed under their own gravity, giving birth to the first stars.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: In the cause of these stars, hydrogen was converted into helium under extreme conditions.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: After millions of years, the hydrogen became exhausted and the stars began dying.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: Under super extreme conditions, all elements we know today were created a fraction of a second before they died and exploded in supernovas.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: They shot most of their contents into space while the cause collapsed and became black holes.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: All these elements traveled through space for who knows how long, until they arrived at a different cloud that was slowly forming a new star, our sun.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: These elements that once were the insights of a star formed planets and found their way onto earth.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: Where they name would life to begin.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: So we are directly connected to the first stars ever born in the universe.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: We are part of the universe.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: The idea of being a deeply connected, minuscule part of an enormous structure is really mind-blowing.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: We don't know what all this means, or if it means anything at all.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: We know that we are made of little parts that connect us to everything in the universe, to the beginning of everything.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: And this is kind of a nice thought.

Title: Are You Alone? (In The Universe)
Sentence: You are not alone, you never were, you never will be.

Title: How to catch a Dwarf Planet -- Triton MM#3
Sentence: The 14 moons of Neptune are a strange bunch.

Title: How to catch a Dwarf Planet -- Triton MM#3
Sentence: Most of them are small potato-shaped pieces of ice and rock.

Title: How to catch a Dwarf Planet -- Triton MM#3
Sentence: Some are so far away from Neptune that they need 29 years to circle Neptune once, almost all of them are asteroids trapped by Neptune's gravity.

Title: How to catch a Dwarf Planet -- Triton MM#3
Sentence: 99.5% of all the mass around Neptune is concentrated in Trism.

Title: How to catch a Dwarf Planet -- Triton MM#3
Sentence: It's the seventh biggest moon and more massive than all other known moons in the solar system that are smaller than itself combined.

Title: How to catch a Dwarf Planet -- Triton MM#3
Sentence: Its surface area is about as big as the mainland of Russia and Australia together.

Title: How to catch a Dwarf Planet -- Triton MM#3
Sentence: Also, Trism is one of only four objects in the solar system that we know is geologically active.

Title: How to catch a Dwarf Planet -- Triton MM#3
Sentence: Trism orbit Neptune in the wrong direction against the rotation of Neptune, which is unique in our solar system from object as big as Trism.

Title: How to catch a Dwarf Planet -- Triton MM#3
Sentence: We can conclude from this that Trism hasn't always been a moon of Neptune, but probably was a dwarf planet that was forced into submission by Neptune when the solar system was younger and more chaotic.

Title: How to catch a Dwarf Planet -- Triton MM#3
Sentence: The most popular theory here is that Trism was one part of a double system.

Title: How to catch a Dwarf Planet -- Triton MM#3
Sentence: When Neptune migrated to the outer edges of the solar system, its gravity interfered with the double system and catapulted the other object into space while Trism was forced into orbit.

Title: How to catch a Dwarf Planet -- Triton MM#3
Sentence: This would have disrupted the orbits of other Neptune moons rather violently and would most likely have either pushed them away from Neptune or let them collide or crash into Neptune.

Title: How to catch a Dwarf Planet -- Triton MM#3
Sentence: This would explain why Neptune's moons are so dominated by Trism.

Title: How to catch a Dwarf Planet -- Triton MM#3
Sentence: But this will end one day.

Title: How to catch a Dwarf Planet -- Triton MM#3
Sentence: Trism is being slowed down by Neptune and eventually it will either crash into it or be ground by Neptune's gravity into a huge ring system similar to Saturn's.

Title: How to catch a Dwarf Planet -- Triton MM#3
Sentence: So don't buy real estate on Trism.

Title: The Moons of Mars Explained -- Phobos & Deimos MM#2
Sentence: The moons of Mars explained.

Title: The Moons of Mars Explained -- Phobos & Deimos MM#2
Sentence: Mars has two moons, fobos and dimos.

Title: The Moons of Mars Explained -- Phobos & Deimos MM#2
Sentence: They are really tiny.

Title: The Moons of Mars Explained -- Phobos & Deimos MM#2
Sentence: How tiny?

Title: The Moons of Mars Explained -- Phobos & Deimos MM#2
Sentence: Compared to Mars or our own moon, pretty tiny.

Title: The Moons of Mars Explained -- Phobos & Deimos MM#2
Sentence: Although tiny is a matter of opinion.

Title: The Moons of Mars Explained -- Phobos & Deimos MM#2
Sentence: Their surface areas are close to some of the smallest states on Earth, like Luxembourg and Malta.

Title: The Moons of Mars Explained -- Phobos & Deimos MM#2
Sentence: Although fobos and dimos are in no way lightweight, in reality their gravitational pool isn't even strong enough to bring them into spherical form, so they look more like huge potatoes than moons.

Title: The Moons of Mars Explained -- Phobos & Deimos MM#2
Sentence: The most popular theory of their origin is that they will once part of the asteroid belt until Jupiter's massive gravity kick them out of it, so Mars could catch them.

Title: The Moons of Mars Explained -- Phobos & Deimos MM#2
Sentence: fobos orbit smart as an average distance of 9,400 kilometers, once every 7,5 hours.

Title: The Moons of Mars Explained -- Phobos & Deimos MM#2
Sentence: Sun a collision course and gets two meters close to Mars every year.

Title: The Moons of Mars Explained -- Phobos & Deimos MM#2
Sentence: In 52,100 million years, it will either be ripped to pieces by Mars's gravity and be transformed into a beautiful ring or it will crash into Mars.

Title: The Moons of Mars Explained -- Phobos & Deimos MM#2
Sentence: The energy released in this collision would kill everything on the small planet, so if there are humans on Mars by then, they should build very strong bunkers.

Title: The Moons of Mars Explained -- Phobos & Deimos MM#2
Sentence: All a dimos on the other hand is slowly escaping Mars.

Title: The Moons of Mars Explained -- Phobos & Deimos MM#2
Sentence: Eventually it will fly off into space and leave a lonely red planet behind.

Title: The Moons of Mars Explained -- Phobos & Deimos MM#2
Sentence: So in a few hundred million years Mars will be moonless and on its own.

Title: The Moons of Mars Explained -- Phobos & Deimos MM#2
Sentence: Unless it manages to catch itself another asteroid.

Title: How Big is the Moon? MM#1

Title: How Big is the Moon? MM#1

Title: How Big is the Moon? MM#1

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: So, have you ever wondered who actually invented the internet?

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: Some people have become zillionaires thanks to the internet, but all they did was invent clever ways of using the internet.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: So the person who invented the internet should be a gazillionaire equivalent to say, God shouldn't they?

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: Who should get the credit then?

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: Was it a British key can a Swiss underground lab?

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: Maybe Clever Americans threatened with nuclear annihilation by the Russians?

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: Nice idea.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: A French scientist who decided to call their computer network the, let's tell it.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: Interesting.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: Or was it thanks to a myriad of small scientists working on something they knew was useful, but didn't realise would be so big.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: Well, let's try and get some facts straight.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: There's the internet, a whole bunch of computer networks connected to each other, and then there's the worldwide web, a way of making it easier to share information using all those interconnected computers.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: The internet, as we know it today, was at least 40 years in the making.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: One popular but wrong story is that the internet was developed by the USA, so they had a communication network that would survive a nuclear war.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: According to one of the founders of the first network, the Arpanet in the 1960s, this first network experiment wasn't about communication at all, it was about optimizing processor usage or time sharing, which basically meant that scientists could share computer power too.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: That was because until the 1960s, there was basically no network, you had big machines called Mainframe, which sat in a room, and processed computing tasks one at a time.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: With time sharing, these biomaths could process several tasks at a time, which meant that power could be used by several scientists at once.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: And obviously, once you start connecting computers together, you start to wonder about what you need to do to make communications between them easier.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: Scientists around the world were trying to solve this problem, so let's look at some of the other key concepts that were developed elsewhere.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: Starting with packet switching.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: In Britain, there was a commercial network developed by the National Physical Laboratory, but which never really got off the ground because it didn't get funding.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: But they did come up with the idea of packet switching, a way of avoiding congestion in busy networks by cutting up days or at one end and putting it out together at the other.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: The French also played a role.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: They were working on a scientific network called Siklardis, but they didn't have a big budget, so they decided to work on direct connections between computers as opposed to working with gateway computers.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: Now, as an aside here, this, it basically isn't very scientific, but according to one theory, a spit-off of their research was the word anti-hannet, but you don't have to believe it if you don't want to.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: So, now it's the early 1970s.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: There's quite a lot of computer infrastructure, but communication is awkward and patchy, because different networks can't talk to each other.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: TCP-IP solves this problem.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: The TCP-IP protocols form the basic communication language of the internet, which labels the packets of data and make sure that even though some pieces of the same data take a different route, they all arrive at their destination and can be reassembled.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: That works really began communicating with each other in 1975, so you could argue that was the beginning of the internet.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: Email was also very important.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: It was developed for Arpanet in 1972.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: Most internet traffic in 1976 was email, because academics thought electronic posted notes were dead call.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: With networks that could talk to each other, communication was becoming easier, but all this communication was just text-based, and it was pretty ugly to look at.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: In the 1980s, a brick called Timothy Bernersly spent time with Sirn, the European Organization for Nuclear Research, where physicists are trying to work out what the universe is made of.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: He wanted to manage the scientist's information, and make it possible for them to share and interconnect their work easily, making progress more likely.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: He did so by inventing an interface using HTTP, HTML, and URLs, that made internet browsers possible.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: He called his browser the World Wide Web, so he didn't invent the internet, but he did invent the web.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: The first ever website which he created was at Sirn in France in August 1991.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: So, once the initial infrastructure was in place, the key technologies had been invented, internet message boards exploded in the 1980s, the phone companies saw the commercial potential of digital communication, web browsers spread like wildfire in the early 1990s, and ordinary people discovered email.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: Then, the internet expanded rapidly and steadily, and became workable for the masses from about 1995.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: Hold on, didn't U.S. Vice President Al Gore invent the internet?

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: Oh no, and if you read what he said exactly, you'd know he never claimed to have done.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: But many people credit him with an energetically pushing legislation that encouraged the spread of the internet.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: The internet exists because we need to communicate, and most of us like doing it.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: That's why humans have become the dominant species on Earth.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: You could argue that the internet is a natural evolutionary step and a manifestation of that need.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: It wasn't invented by anyone in particular, but when the building blocks were put together by all those cool scientists from all over the place, the internet became a communication tool, a retail tool, a research tool, a propaganda tool, a spying tool, a shopping tool, a dating tool, an entertainment tool, and a way of sciving off work while making it look like you're working or studying, which is what you may be doing now.

Title: Who Invented the Internet? And Why?
Sentence: Ultimately, though, you're communicating, especially if you leave a comment, and that might make you a better human being.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: The beginning of everything, the Big Bang.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: The idea that the universe was suddenly born and is not infinite.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: Up to the middle of the 20th century, most scientists thought of the universe as infinite and ageless.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: Until Einstein's theory of relativity gave us a better understanding of gravity and Edwin Hubble discovered that galaxies are moving apart from one another in a way that fits previous predictions.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: In 1964, by accident, cosmic background radiation was discovered, a relic of the early universe, which together with other observational evidence made the Big Bang the accepted theory in science.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: Since then, improved technology like the Hubble telescope has given us a pretty good picture of the Big Bang and the structure of the cosmos.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: Recent observations, even seemed to suggest that the expansion of the universe is accelerating.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: But how did this Big Bang work?

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: How can something come from nothing?

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: Let's explore what we know.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: We can ignore the beginning part for now.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: First of all, the Big Bang was not an explosion.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: It was all space stretching everywhere all at once.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: The universe started very, very, very small and quickly expanded to the size of a football.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: The universe didn't expand into anything, space was just expanding into itself.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: The universe cannot expand into anything because the universe has no borders, there is by definition no outside the universe.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: The universe is all there is.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: In this hot dense environment, energy manifested itself in particles that existed only for the tiniest glimpses of time.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: From gluons, pairs of quarks were created, which destroyed one another, perhaps after giving off more gluons.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: These found other short lived quarks to interact with, forming new quark pairs and gluons again.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: Matter and energy were not just theoretically equivalent, it was so hot, they were practically the same stuff.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: So we're around this time, matter one over antimatter.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: Today, we're left with almost all matter and nearly no antimatter at all.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: Somehow, one billion and one matter particles were formed for everyone billion particles of antimatter.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: Instead of one massive ultimate force in the universe, there were now several refined versions of it acting under different rules.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: By now, the universe has stretched to a billion kilometers in diameter, which leads to a decrease in temperature.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: The cycle of quarks being born and converted back to energy suddenly stops.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: From now on, we work with what we have.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: Quarks begin forming new particles, headrons, like protons and neutrons.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: There are many, many combinations of quarks that can form all sorts of hydrons, but only very few are reasonably stable for any length of time.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: Please take a moment to appreciate that by now, only one second has passed since the beginning of everything.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: The universe, which has grown to 100 billion kilometers, is now called enough to allow most of the neutrons to decay into protons and form the first atom hydrogen.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: Imagine the universe at this point as an extremely hot soup.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: 10 billion degrees Celsius filled with countless particles and energy.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: Over the next few minutes, things cooled and settled down very fast.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: Atoms formed out of hydrons and electrons, making for a stable and electrically neutral environment.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: Some call this period the dark age, because there were no stars of the hydrogen gas didn't allow visible light to move around.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: What's the meaning of visible light anyway when there's nothing alive yet that could have eyes?

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: When the hydrogen gas clumped together after millions of years and gravity put it under great pressure, stars and galaxies began to fall.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: Their radiation dissolved the stable hydrogen gas into a plasma that still permeates the universe today and allows visible light to pass.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: Finally, there was light.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: OK, but what about the part we didn't talk about?

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: What happened right at the beginning?

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: This part can be defined as the big bang.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: We don't know at all what happened here.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: At this point, our tools break down.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: Natural laws stop making sense, time itself becomes wibbly wobbly.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: To understand what happened here, we need a theory that unifies Einstein's relativity and quantum mechanics, something countless scientists are working on right now.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: But this leaves us with lots of unanswered questions.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: By their universes before our own, is this the first and only universe?

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: What started the big bang or did it just occur naturally based on laws we don't understand yet?

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: We don't know and maybe we never will.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: But what we do know is that the universe as we know it started here and gave birth to particles, galaxies, stars, the earth and you.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: Since we ourselves are made of dead stars, we are not separate from the universe.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: We are part of it.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: You could even say that we are the universe's way of experiencing itself.

Title: The Beginning of Everything -- The Big Bang
Sentence: So let's keep on experiencing it until there are no more questions to ask.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: One day the universe will die, but why and how and will the universe be dead forever?

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: And how do we know that?

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: First of all, the universe is expanding.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: I'm not only that, the rate of its expansion is accelerating.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: The reason, dark energy.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: Dark energy is a strange phenomenon that scientists believe permeates the universe.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: Until 1998, we thought that the universe must work a bit like a ball that you throw into the sky.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: The ball moves up, but at some point it has to come down again.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: But the expansion of the universe is actually speeding up.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: That's like throwing a ball up and watching it fly away faster and faster and faster.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: Where is this acceleration coming from?

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: Well, we don't know, but we call it dark energy.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: Einstein thought of it first and then decided it was stupid.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: Now, astrophysicists have decided it is plausible.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: Troubles, this is all very theoretical, and we don't actually know what the properties of dark energy are.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: But there are various theories, and they lead us to three scenarios for the end of the universe.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: One, the Big Rib.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: Since it's both, the universe has been expanding.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: For unknown reasons, new space is created everywhere equally.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: The space between galaxies expands, so they move apart.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: The space inside galaxies also expands, but here gravity is strong enough to keep them together.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: In the Big Rib scenario, the expansion accelerates up to a point where space expands so fast, the gravity can't compensate for this effect anymore.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: The result is a big rib.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: At first, only large structures like galaxies are torn apart, since space between the single objects expands very fast.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: Next, Big Bodies like black holes, stars, and planet's die.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: Their gravity isn't strong enough to keep them together, so they dissolve into their components.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: In the end, space would expand faster than the speed of light.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: Atoms would now be affected, and they would just disband.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: One space is expanding faster than light, no particle in the universe can interact with any other particle anymore.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: The universe would dissolve into countless, lowly particles that won't be able to touch anything else in a strange, timeless universe.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: Hmm, and you thought you felt lonely?

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: Two, heat death, or a big freeze.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: In a nutshell, the difference between the Big Rib and Heat Death is that in a heat death scenario, matter stays intact, and is converted over an incredibly long but finite period of time into radiation, while the universe expands forever.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: But how does this work?

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: Let's talk about entropy.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: Every system tends to wards the state of highest entropy, like when we have a Latin Machiazo.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: Initially, it has different regions, but over time they will cool down and disintegrate until it's uniform.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: And this also applies to the universe.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: So while the universe gets bigger and bigger, matter slowly decays and spreads out.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: At some point, after lots of generations of stars, all the gas clouds necessary to form stars will be exhausted, so the universe will turn dark.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: The remaining suns will die.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: Black holes will slowly degenerate and evaporate over trillions of years, due to what's known as Hawking Radiation.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: When this process is complete, only a dilute gas of photons and light particles remains until even this decays.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: All activity in the universe ceases at this point.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: Entropy is at its maximum, and the universe is dead forever.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: Unless theoretically it might be possible that after an incredibly long amount of time, there might be a spontaneous entropy decrease as a result of something called quantum tunneling, leading to a new big bang.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: Three big crunch and big bounce.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: This is the most uplifting scenario.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: If there is less dark energy than we think or it decreases over time, gravity will be the dominating force in the universe one day.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: In a few trillion years, the rate of expansion of the universe will slow down and stop.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: After that, it reverses.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: Galaxy's will race at each other, merging as the universe becomes smaller and smaller.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: Since the smaller universe also means a hotter universe, temperatures rise everywhere all at once.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: 100,000 years before the big crunch, background radiation would be hotter than the surfaces of most stars, which means that they would be cooked from the outside.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: Minutes before the big crunch happens, atom cores are ripped apart before super-messive black holes devour everything.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: Finally, all black holes would merge into a super-messive mega-black hole that contains the entire mass of the universe, and in the last moment before the big crunch, it would devour the universe, including itself.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: The big bounce theory states that this has happened a lot of times, and that the universe goes through an infinite cycle of expansion and contraction.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: Well, wouldn't that be nice?

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: So what will actually happen to the universe in the end?

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: At the moment, heat death seems the most likely, but we at Cutskazard hope that this dead forever stuff is wrong, and the universe will start over and over again.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: We don't know for sure either way, so let's just assume the most uplifting theory is true.

Title: Three Ways to Destroy the Universe
Sentence: By the way, we have a Twitter account.

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: Time makes sense in small pieces.

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: But when you look at huge stretches of time, it's almost impossible to wrap your head around things.

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: So, let's start small with minutes, hours, days.

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: You probably spent the last 24 hours mostly sleeping and working with some coffee less on wet.

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: Please watch less TV.

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: Now let's look at 2013.

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: Relatively unnoticed, Hitler's bodyguard died at the age of 96, while in June, Edward Snowden started the NSA scandal.

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: Moving back a bit, the 21st century is still pretty young and largely shaped by the attacks on 9-11 that ultimately led to the 30-hrark war.

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: Oh, and Facebook and smartphones took over our lives.

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: But we're just getting started.

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: Let's back up further.

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: The 20th century has seen its share of conflicts, too.

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: After two devastating world wars, the Cold War lasted for almost the whole second half of it.

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: An average human lifespan covers most of this stuff as well as the birth of the internet and the beginning of the information age.

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: The oldest living person on Earth is currently Miss Howe O'Kalur, who was born in 1898, which means that her birth was closer to Napoleon ruling Europe than to the current day.

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: The last 500 years of human history brought enormous changes to our lifestyles.

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: Industrialization gave rise to new ideas like communism.

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: Farmers became workers and knowledge became easier to distribute.

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: The theory of evolution changed how we saw ourselves and the world we live in, all in a few hundred years.

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: The 15th century was very eventful.

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: Columbus's discovery of America and the fall of Constantinople marked the end of the Middle Ages.

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: People in the Middle Ages were super into war over Territory and Religion, but the Black plague was far more efficient than war, killing every third European in six years.

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: Arriving in the common era, let's take a look where we came from.

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: Our current century is tiny and 2013 is barely visible.

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: This is recorded human history.

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: The pyramids were constructed 4,500 years ago.

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: The peak of the Roman Empire was 2,000 years ago.

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: So to the Romans, the pyramids were as old as the Romans are to us today.

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: History starts with writing, but what happened before that?

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: About 12,000 years ago, the agricultural revolution took place.

Title: The History and Future of Everything -- Time
Sentence: Man kind began farming, which gave rise to the existence of cities and larger communities.
