Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: What is the stock exchange and how does it work?

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: The stock exchange is nothing more than a giant, globally network tender organized marketplace, where every day huge sums of money are moved back and forth.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: In total of 60 trillion euros a year, a traded.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: More than the value of all goods and services of the entire world economy.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: However, it's not apples or second hand toothbrushes that are traded on this marketplace, but predominantly securities.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: Securities are right to assets mostly in the form of shares.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: A share stands for a share in a company.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: But why are shares traded at all?

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: Well, first and foremost, the value of a share relates to a company behind it.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: If you think of the value of the company in terms of a pizza, the bigger the overall size of the pizza, the bigger every piece is.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: If, for example, Facebook is able to break the increase its profits with a new business model, the size of the company's pizza will also increase, and as a result, so will the value of its shares.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: This is of course great for the shareholders.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: A share which perhaps used to be worth 38 euros could now be worth a whole 50 euros.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: When it's sold, this represents a profit of 12 euros per share, but what does Facebook gain from this?

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: The company can raise funds by setting the shares and invest or expand its business.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: Facebook, for example, has earned $16 billion from its listing on the stock exchange.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: The trading of shares, though, is frequently a game of chance.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: No one can say which company will perform well and which will not.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: If a company has a good reputation, investors will back it.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: A company with a poor reputation or poor performance will have difficulty selling its shares.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: Unlike a normal market in which goods can be touched and taken home, on the stock exchange only virtual goods are available.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: They appear in the form of share prices and tables on monitors.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: Such share prices can rise or fall within seconds.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: Shareholders, therefore, have to act quickly in order not to miss an opportunity.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: Even a simple rumor can result in a demand for a share falling fast, regardless of the real value of the company.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: Of course, the opposite is also possible.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: If a particularly large number of people buy weak shares, because they see, for example, great potential behind an idea, their value will rise as a result.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: In particular, young companies can benefit from this.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: Even though their sales might be falling, they can generate cash by placing their shares.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: In the best case scenario, this will result in their idea being turned into reality.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: In the worst case scenario, this will result in a speculative bubble with nothing more than hot air.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: And, as in the case with bubbles, at some point, they will burst.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: The value of Germany's biggest 30 companies is summarised in what's known as the DAX share index.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: The DAX curve shows how well or poorly these major companies, and thereby the economy as a whole, are performing at the present time.

Title: How The Stock Exchange Works (For Dummies)
Sentence: Stock exchanges and other countries also have their own indices, and all of these markets together create a globally networked marketplace.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: The ocean conveyor belt and the Gulf Stream.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: Ocean currents have a direct influence on our lives.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: They determine our weather, our climate, and much more.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: The ocean currents and wind systems transport heat from the equator to the poles and operate like a large engine for the global climate.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: In the oceans, there are numerous currents.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: The so-called ocean conveyor belt is very important for our climate.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: This term describes a combination of currents that result in the four of the five global oceans exchange in water with each other.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: They form a worldwide circulation system.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: The conveyor belt is also called the thermo-heline circulation, with thermo referring to the temperature and helined to the salt content of the water.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: Both determine the density of the water.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: While the masses of water may be moved in part by wind, primarily the different densities of the global oceans are responsible for their movement.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: Warm water has a lower density and rises.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: While cold water sinks, the water's density also increases with a higher salt content.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: The equator that heat from the sun is especially strong, resulting in a lot of evaporation and that's a rise in the water's salt content.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: That is where the Gulf Stream begins.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: The Gulf Stream is very important for the European climate.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: Its length of 10,000 kilometers makes it one of the largest and fastest ocean currents on earth, and it's very warm.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: At roughly 2 metres a second, it brings up to 100 million cubic metres of water per second towards Europe.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: A constantly blowing wind that southeast trade wind drives warm surface water to the northwest into the Gulf of Mexico, where it heats up 230°C.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: The turning of the earth and the west winds then direct the Gulf Stream towards Europe and split it up.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: One part flows south, another east to the Canary current, and a third part flows north, where it releases a lot of heat into the atmosphere as the north Atlantic current.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: The water becomes colder there.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: Its salt content and density rise on account of evaporation and it drops down between Greenland, Norway and Iceland.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: There we also find the largest waterfall on earth.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: The so-called Chimneys, roughly 15 kilometer wide pillars with water falling up to 4,000 metres.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: 17 million cubic metres of water per second, or roughly 15 times more water than is carried by all the rivers in the world.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: This creates a strong mail-strom which constantly pulls in new water and is the reason that the Gulf Stream moves towards Europe.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: Countless species use the Gulf Stream as a means of transport on their trips from the Caribbean to northern areas.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: But it doesn't just bring us animals, and enormous quantity of warm air also comes with it.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: In order to reduce the same heat which it brings to the shores of Europe, we would need 1 million nuclear power plants.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: That's why we also call the Gulf Stream a heat pump.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: Without it, the temperature would be significantly colder here at least 5 to 10 degrees.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: Instead of lush fields, we would have long winters and sparse ice-covered landscapes in Europe.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: In the last few years, scientists and pundits in the media have repeatedly expressed the fear that the Gulf Stream could come to a standstill due to climate change.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: Because if the polar caps actually melt, the salt content in the water off Greenland would fall as would its density.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: The North Atlantic current would no longer be heavy enough, and so it wouldn't sink as usual.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: In the worst case, that would bring the Gulf Stream our heat pump to a stop.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: Some climate experts also assume that climate change could compensate for this effect.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: We know that it can be normal for the climate to change by looking at the development of the Earth over the last few million years.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: There are ice ages and warm periods.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: In the last ice age, a gigantic flood of melting water crippled the heat-bring North Atlantic current covering the northern hemisphere in ice.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: Scientists have different views on the impact that climate change will have on the global ocean conveyor belt.

Title: The Gulf Stream Explained
Sentence: But one thing is clear, when the climate changes, then the complex system of ocean currents and winds which has remained fairly stable since the last ice age, will change in ways that we don't yet understand.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: What is hydraulic fretting or fracking?

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: Since the industrial revolution, our energy consumption has risen unceasingly.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: The majority of this energy consumption is supplied by fossil fuels, like coal or natural gas.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: Recently, there's been a lot of talk about a controversial method of extracting natural gas, hydraulic fretting or fracking.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: Put simply, fracking describes the recovery of natural gas from deep layers inside the earth.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: In this method, porous rock is fractured by the use of water, sand and chemicals.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: In order to release the enclosed natural gas, the technique of fracking has been known since the 1940s.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: Nonetheless, only in the last 10 years has there been quite a fracking boom, especially in the USA.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: This is because most conventional natural gas sources in America and on the European continent have been exhausted.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: Thus, prices for natural gas and other fuels are rising steadily.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: Signifiably more complicated and expensive methods, like fracking, have now become attractive and profitable.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: In the meantime, fracking has already been used more than a million times in the USA alone.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: Over 60% of all new oil and gas wells are drilled by using fracking.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: Now, let's take a look at how fracking actually works.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: First, a shaft is drilled several hundred metres into the earth.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: From there, a horizontal hole is drilled into the gas bearing layer of rock.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: Next, the fracking fluid is pumped into the ground using high performance pumps.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: On average, the fluid consists of eight million litres of water, which amounts to about the daily consumption of 65,000 people, plus several thousand tons of sand and about 200,000 litres of chemicals.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: The mixture penetrates into the rock layer and produces innumerable tiny cracks.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: The sand prevents the cracks from closing again.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: The chemicals perform various tasks.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: Among other things, they compress the water, kill off bacteria or dissolve minerals.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: Next, the majority of the fracking fluid is pumped out again.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: And now, the natural gas can be recovered.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: As soon as the gas source is exhausted, the drill hole is sealed.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: As a rule, the fracking fluid is pumped back into deep underground layers and sealed in there.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: However, fracking is also associated with several considerable risks.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: The primary risk consists in the contamination of drinking water sources.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: Fracking not only consumes large quantities of fresh water, but in addition, the water is subsequently contaminated and is highly toxic.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: The contamination is so severe that the water cannot even be cleaned in a treatment plant.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: Even though the dangerous known and theoretically could be managed, in the USA already, sources have been contaminated due to negligence.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: No one yet knows how the enclosed water will behave in the future, since there have not yet been any long-term studies on the subject.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: The chemicals used in fracking vary from the hazardous to the extremely toxic and carcinogenic, such as benzol or formic acid.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: The company is using fracking say nothing about the precise composition of the chemical mixture.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: But it is known that there are about 700 different chemical agents which can be used in the process.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: Another risk is the release of greenhouse gases.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: The natural gas recovered by fracking consists largely of methane, a greenhouse gas which is 25 times more potent than carbon dioxide.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: Natural gas is less harmful than coal when burned.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: But nonetheless, the negative effects of fracking on the climate balance are overall greater.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: Firstly, the fracking process requires a very large consumption of energy.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: Secondly, the drill holes are quickly exhausted and it's necessary to drill fracking holes much more frequently than for classical natural gas wells.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: In addition, about 3% of the recovered gas is lost in the extraction and escapes into the atmosphere.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: So how it's fracking and its expected benefits to be assessed when the advantages are balanced against the disadvantages?

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: When properly employed, this technique offers one way in the short-term medium term to meet our demand for lower cost energy.

Title: Fracking explained: opportunity or danger
Sentence: But the long-term consequences of fracking are unforeseeable and the risk to our drinking water thus should not be underestimated.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: The solar system, our home, in space.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: We live in a peaceful part of the Milky Way.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Our home is the solar system, a four and a half billion-year-old formation that races around the Galactic Center at 200,000 kmph and circles it once every 250 million years.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: The star, the sun, is at the center of the solar system.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: It's orbited by eight planets, trillions of asteroids and comets and a few dwarf planets.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: The eight planets are divided into four planets like ours.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars, and four gas giants, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Mercury is the smallest and lightest of all the planets.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: A Mercury year is shorter than a Mercury day, which leads to enormous fluctuations in temperature.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Mercury does not have an atmosphere or a moon.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Venus is one of the brightest objects in the solar system and by far the hottest planet, with atmospheric pressure that is 92 times higher than on Earth.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: When out of control greenhouse effect means that Venus never cools below 437 degrees Celsius.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Venus also doesn't have a moon.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Earth is our home and the only planet with temperatures that are moderate enough to allow for a surplus of liquid water.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Furthermore, it's so far the only place where life is known to exist.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: The Earth has one moon.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Mars is the second smallest planet in the solar system and hardly massive enough to keep a very thin atmosphere.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: It's a lumpus monster's largest mountain in the solar system, more than three times as high as Mount Everest.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Mars has two small moons.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Jupiter is the largest and most massive planet in the solar system.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: It consists largely of hydrogen and helium and is the theatre for the largest and most powerful storms we know.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Its largest storm, the Great Red Spot, is three times as large as Earth.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Jupiter has 67 moons.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Satellis the second largest planet and possesses the smallest density of all the planets.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: If you had a sufficiently large bathtub, Saturn would swim in it.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Saturn is also known for its extended, very visible ring system.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: It has 62 moons.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Uranus is the third largest planet and one of the coldest.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Of all the gas giants, it's also the smallest.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: The special thing about Uranus is that its axis of rotation is tilted sideways in contrast to the seven other planets.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: It has 27 moons.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Neptune is the last planet in the solar system and is similar to Uranus.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: It's so far removed from the sun that a Neptune year is 164 Earth years long.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: The highest wind speed ever measured was in a storm on Neptune at just under 2,100 kilometers per hour.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Neptune has 14 moons.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: If we compare the sizes of the planets, the differences between them become even clearer.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Jupiter is the leader in terms of size and weight.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Small Mercury, on the other hand, is even smaller than one of Jupiter's moons, Ganymeat.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Jupiter is so massive that alone it contains roughly 70% of the mass of all the other planets and has a massive impact on its surroundings.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: That's a blessing for Earth since Jupiter draws most of the dangerously large asteroids that could wipe out life on Earth.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: And even Jupiter is a dwarf in comparison to our star, the Sun.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Calling it massive does not do justice to the Sun.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: It makes up 99.86% of the mass in our solar system.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: For the most part, it consists of hydrogen and helium.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Only less than 2% is made up of heavy elements like oxygen or iron.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: At its core, the Sun fuses 620 million tons of hydrogen each second and generates enough energy to satisfy mankind's needs for years.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: But not only the eight planets orbit our Sun, trillions of asteroids and comets also circulate.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Most of them are concentrated into two belts, the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter and the Kipa belt at the edge of the solar system.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: These belts are home to countless objects, some as large as a dust particle, others the size of dwarf planets.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: The most well-known object in the asteroid belt is Saras.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: The most well-known objects in the Kipa belt are Pluto, Make Make and Hamaya.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Usually, we describe the asteroid belt the dense collection of bodies that constantly collide.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: But in fact, the asteroids are distributed across an area that is so indescribably large that it's even difficult to see two asteroids at once.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Despite the billions of objects in them, the asteroid belts are fairly empty places.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: And nonetheless, there are collisions over and over again.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: The mass of both belts is also unimpressive.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: The asteroid belt has a little less than 4% of our moons Mars.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: And the Kipa belt is only between 125th and 110th of Earth's mass.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: One day the solar system will cease to exist.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: The sun will die and mercury Venus and maybe Earth 2 will be destroyed.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: In 500 million years, it will become hotter and hotter until at some point it will melt Earth's crust.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Then the sun will grow and grow and either swallow Earth.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Or at least turn it into a sea of lava.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: When it has burnt up all its fuel and lost most of its mass, it will shrink to a white dwarf and burnt gently for a few billion more years before it goes out entirely.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Then at the latest, life in the solar system will no longer be possible.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: The Milky Way will not even notice it.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: A small part of it in one of its arms will become just a tiny bit darker and mankind will cease to exist.

Title: The Solar System -- our home in space
Sentence: Or leave the solar system in search of a new home.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Mechanisms of Evolution Mechanisms of Evolution What is evolution?

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Evolution is the development of life on Earth.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: This is a process that began billions of years ago and is still continuing to this day.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Evolution tells us how it was possible for the enormous diversity of life to develop.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: It shows us how primitive protozoa could become the millions of different species that we see today.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Evolution then is the answer to the question that we have all our students seeing a accent and a great day together.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: How is it possible for ancestors to have descendants that look so very different to them?

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: In answering this question, we want to focus on animals, excluding other forms of life such as fungi and plants.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: The first question to ask is therefore, how can one animal develop into a whole new species of animal?

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Ah, but just a quick question.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: What exactly is the species?

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: A species is a community of animals that is capable of producing offspring with one another with those offspring also being capable of reproducing and turn.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: To understand this answer better, we need to take a closer look at the following points.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: The uniqueness of living creatures guarantee through the excess production of offspring and heresity and as a second key point selection.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Let's begin with uniqueness.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Every creature that exists is unique and this is essential for evolution.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: The members of a species may strongly resemble each other in appearance, however, they all have slightly different traits and characteristics.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: They may be a bit bigger, fatter, stronger or bolder than their fellow animals.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: So what is the reason for these differences?

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Let's take a closer look at a creature.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Every creature is made up of cells.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: These cells have a nucleus.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: The nucleus contains the chromosome.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: And the chromosomes hold the DNA.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: DNA consists of different genes, and it's these genes that are life's information carriers.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: They contain instructions and orders for the cells and determine the characteristics and traits that living creatures have.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: And it's precisely this DNA that is unique to every creature.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: It's slightly different from individual to individual, which is why each has slightly different characteristics.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: But how is the enormous range of DNA created?

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: One key factor is the excess production of offspring.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: In nature, we can observe that creatures generally produce far more offspring than is necessary for the survival of their species, with many offspring dying and early death as a result.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Often there are even more offspring than the environment in which they live is able to support.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: This is one factor in increasing diversity within a species.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: The more offspring that are produced, the more little differences occur.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: And this is what nature wants, as many little differences as possible.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: The second major cause of the uniqueness of individuals occurs in heredity itself.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: By the way, heredity means the passing on of DNA to offspring.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Two very interesting factors come into play in this process.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Recommodation and mutation.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Recommodation is the random mixing of the DNA of two creatures.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: When two creatures fall in love and mate, they recombine their genes twice.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: The first time they do this separately, when they generate the gamets, that is sperm and exels.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: The gamets take half of the genes and shuffle them.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: The second recombination occurs when in male inseminates a female.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: The parents each provide 50% of their DNA, in other words 50% of their unique traits and characteristics.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: These are then recombined or mixed, and the result is new offspring.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: These offspring have a random mix of the DNA, and therefore the traits and characteristics of their parents.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: This increases the diversity and differences within a species even further.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: But mutations are also important for evolution.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Mutations are random changes in DNA.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: These can also be described as copying errors within the DNA, triggered by toxins or other chemical substances or by radiation.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: A mutation exists when a part of the DNA is altered.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: These changes are often negative and may result in illnesses such as cancer.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: However, they may also have neutral or positive effects such as the blue eye colour in humans, which is one such random mutation.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: In all cases, a mutation has to affect a gamet, that is a sperm or exel.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Because only the DNA in the gamets is passed on to the offspring.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: This is also the reason why we protect our sexual organs during x-rays whilst other parts of the body are not at risk.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: In summary, then, in the heredity process, creatures pass on their characteristics to their offspring in the form of DNA.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Recommodation and mutation change the DNA so that each child looks different to its siblings and receives a random mix of the characteristics of its parents.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: There's a key word here.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Random.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: All of these processes are based on chance.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Random recombination and mutations result in individuals with random mixes of traits and characteristics which in turn mix these randomly and pass them on.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: But how can so much be down to chance when all living creatures are so perfectly adapted to their environment?

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: For example, the stick insect, the hummingbird, and the frogfish.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: The answer is provided by the second key point selection.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Each individual is subjected to a process of natural selection.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: As we have learned, each individual is somewhat different to its fellows.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: And there is extensive variation within a species.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Environmental influences have an effect on living creatures, these so-called selection factors include...

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Predators, parasites, animals of the same species, toxins, changes in habitat, or the climate.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Selection is a process that each individual is subjected to.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Every creature has a unique mix of traits and characteristics.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: This mix helps them to survive in their environment, or not, as the case may be.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Anyone with an unsuitable mix will be selected from the environment.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Those with the right mix survive and can pass on their enhanced traits and characteristics.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: This is why diversity is so important.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: This is why creatures make so much effort to produce offspring that are as different as possible.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: They increase the likelihood that at least one of their offspring passes nature's selection process.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: They maximize their chances of survival.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: A good example of this can be seen in a group of fintures living on a remote island.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: They are some of the most famous animals in the world of science, and are known as Darwin fintures after their discovery Charles Darwin.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: And this is the story of those fintures.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: A few hundred years ago, a small group of fintures was blown onto the Galapica silence in the middle of the Pacific, probably by a big storm.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: The fintures found themselves in an environment that was completely new to them, a real finture paradise, an abundance of food and no predators.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: They reproduced rapidly and numerously.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: The islands were soon heaving with fintures.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: This meant that food supplies became increasingly scarce.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: The fintge paradise was threatened with famine and fintge friends became competitors.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: This is when selection intervened.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Their individuality and small differences, in this case their slightly different beaks, meant that some of the birds were able to avoid competing with their fellow fintures.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: The beaks of some of the fintures were more suitable for digging for worms.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Other fintures were able to use their beaks better for cracking seeds.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: The fintures consequently sought out ecological niches.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: In these niches, they were safe from excessive competition.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: They soon began to mate primarily with other fintures that used the same niche.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Over the course of many generations, these characteristics were enhanced, enabling the fintures to exploit their niches successfully.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: The differences between the worm diggers and the seed crackers became so large that they were no longer able to mate with one another.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Different species emerged as a result.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Today there are 14 different species of fintch living on the Galapica Islands, all of which are descended from the same group of stranded fintures.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: This is how new species are created by evolution.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Through the interaction of unique individuals, the excess production of offspring, Re-combination and mutation in heredity, and finally through selection.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Why is this so important?

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: It tells us whether variety of life comes from and why living creatures are so perfectly adapted to their habitats.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: But it also affects us personally.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Every person is the result of 3.5 billion years of evolution.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: And that includes you.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Your ancestors fought and adapted in order to survive.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: This survival was an extremely uncertain thing.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: If we consider the fact that 99% of all the species that have ever lived are extinct, then you can consider yourself part of a success story.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: The dinosaurs have disappeared, but you are alive watching this video.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: Because you're incredibly special, just like all the other creatures that exist today.

Title: How Evolution works
Sentence: A reproducible and unique in the universe.
